quote: It probably sounded terrific in the pitch meeting.
Seems derivative of so many other movies that you're surprised that it doesn't have to credit its sources the way hip-hop artists do when they sample songs.
From an acting standpoint, you won't find more wood this side of a lumber yard.
It's all just cheap metaphor and stupid spectacle, with technology standing (rather inadequately) in for any sort of genuine inquiry into the fascinating mysteries and difficulties of actual faith.
The film short-changes its own dramatic build by employing cheap cutaways and less than seamless editing.
For a film about the ultimate triumph of Good over Evil, Bless the Child sure is bleak and moody.
Let's hope Smits didn't quit the 15th Precinct for this crap.
To call Bless the Child ridiculous doesn't begin to cover it.
This hodgepodge couldn't have been salvaged by the most expert handling, but the execution here is pallid at best.
Too much of a bloodfest to let the characters progress beyond stereotypes, too much of a special effects extravaganza to be really tense, too draggy to really captivate audiences.
As usually happens with films as self-important and derivative as Bless the Child, by the third act this is simply laugh-out-loud funny.
The film starts off with a mediocre premise, and then quickly and progressively becomes more ludicrous as it proceeds.
There are too many tricks and there's too little compelling plot here.
I should be blessed for sitting through that movie.
This is supposed to be a chilling occult thriller. Puh!
There's an old saying: Bless the Child, spare the Audience. And you'd wished the producers thought about this before spending millions on this lame turkey.
Bless the child. But damn the movie.
Bless the Child is rubbish.
[A] perfunctory blend of cheap shocks and fashionable murkiness.
This misguided attempt at redoing The Omen for Touched by an Angel ... was also touched by a hack.
As satanic flicks go, Bless the Child is entertaining, but it doesn't add enough to the genre to make it truly blessed.

Any minute now, I expect the National Association for the Permanent Advancement of Lucifer's Minions (NAPALM) to protest its release, on the grounds that it portrays Satan-worshippers as complete idiots.
Chocked with every bad satanic cliche imaginable, Bless the Child is like Rosemary's Baby (1968) on steroids.
Bless the Child is almost bad enough to become a cult classic.
Considering how jaded moviegoers are these days, it's going to take a lot more than dreck like this to get rise out of them.
A schlocky thriller that might appeal to less discriminating members of the mall crowd.
In times when special effects can show us anything, is it so much to ask to make several thousand crawling rats look at least realistic?
Basinger continues to prove her Oscar win for L.A. Confidential was a fluke.
An adequate but unspectacular fright fest.
Barely squeezes any sense out of its clich√©-ridden plot, with wasted talent, cheezy effects, bad dialogue and unintentional laughs to boot.
It isn't scary. Unintentionally funny, certainly, but rarely frightening.
Egad. How this awful thriller got made is beyond me.
Everything remotely interesting in this movie is overwhelmed by plot silliness and Basinger's terrible central performance.
Bless the Child is a demonstration of the evil of banality.
Bless the Child plays like stick-figure theater.

Planning to lighten your wallet to gawk at this train wreck for a couple of hours? Here's a better idea: Shred up a few handfuls of fives and ones and use them to line the cage of your child's pet gerbil.

Except for a few computerized demons here and there, some scattered Biblical references, and two or three parallels to Jesus, the film was not all that supernatural. And it wasn't all that thrilling either.
As if we hadn't suffered enough at the hands of last winter's (forgotten but not forgiven) End of Days, here comes Bless the Child.
[Chuck Russell's] ineptitude transforms the film from merely bad into howlingly, comically incompetent.
Avoid this piece of hokem like the plague.
A feature length production of stale dialogue with a weak protagonist.
The film is actually pretty creepy despite its strident predictability, and I found myself jumping in places I didn't expect.
Formulaic occult thriller.
Lapses into an exercise in foolishness.
Just when you thought the summer couldn't get any dumber, along comes Bless the Child, acting like someone dropped it on its pointy little head.
Bless the Child is pop junk, an airport paperback, literally, turned into a mid-budget devil thriller.
Those bat-winged CGI demons and red-eyed rats of hell ... should have been banished to a video game before they could transform this solemn shocker into a silly spook show.
The scariest thing about this hokey bombast is that it got made in the first place.
Isn't genuinely scary enough to suppress the inevitable urge to laugh at its cheesy inconsistencies, but isn't howlingly funny enough to raise it to the level of genius.
After a slow start, it becomes enjoyably creepy, only to decline sharply into a morass of ever more inane ridiculousness.
The deflatingly ordinary Bless the Child causes one to wish ... that movies about the supernatural could make contact with supernatural script doctors.
Many special effects are obvious frauds: rubbery rats with unconvincingly red eyes, flying monkeys that make you nostalgic for The Wizard of Oz.
Bless the Child has the static, bland look of a TV movie.
The unintentional effect of movies like Bless the Child is that they are enough to make agnostics out of true believers.
If you're interested in movies about extremely talented children with special powers, it's better to just rent The Sixth Sense.
Everyone in the film looks as if they're doing penance.
End of Days, cheesy as it was, comes nowhere near the glorious pandering and manipulation of Bless the Child.
The whole thing's grotesque as a gargoyle and ugly as sin.
Hackneyed script, shoddy direction, flat acting and laughable, cheesy special effects.
Remarkably unscary and unsuspenseful moments.
Bless the Child may be on the side of the angels but lacks the impact of its cinematic predecessors.
Director Chuck Russell ... plays this like high drama, preventing all the potential camp humor and cheap thrills from bursting forth. And the film drags.
A genuinely creepy experience.
Basinger appears to be gaily waltzing through a soap opera while the other cast members are screeching their way through a horror film.
Must the makers of Bless the Child bang us over the head with symbolism?
Blotchily photographed, robotically acted, uncommonly tone-deaf and all the more depressing because its plot has a certain internal logic and proceeds with something like deliberation.
This hopelessly cliched horror flick touches all the usual bases without much style or imagination.
A very bad movie.
Chuck Russell's direction is lackluster and the special-effects are limited to computer-generated rats and demons.

The formula works and producer Larry Kasanoff and director John Leonetti don't swerve too far from it. Annihilation is basically back-to-back exquisitely choreographed high-tech fantasy fight scenes accompanied by a high-energy techno beat.
It's just an excuse for a series of tedious, repetitious fight scenes that have been staged with no hint whatsoever of originality.
There's a kind of grand awfulness about it.
As far as the plot, the repetitive bombardment of similar scenarios makes the film seem very long and painfully drawn out.
Plot, character, motivation, you ask? C'mon!
Many of the fight scenes are boring to a fault.
Witless, charmless and clueless.
There is nothing... I repeat, nothing worthwhile in this film.
Aided by a one dimensional set that isn't clever enough to be comic-like, this film has a Neanderthal mentality.
You know that when an acting joke like Christopher Lambert won't even return for the sequel, some fragile line has been crossed.
Please, folks, unless you feel like there is nothing left for you in this world and want to end it all, avoid this film at all costs.
A dopey, badly acted and headache-inducing bore.
Its dazzling special effects make its combatants flip and fly, spin and soar, all the while punching and kicking each other like jackhammers, only to leave viewers utterly unmoved.
Here, we have stereotyped villains involved in a generic, high- level conspiracy, and a couple of equally-bland heroes on the run.

There isn't a brain in its empty little head, or in its assembly-line story, which is about how Charlie Sheen pauses occasionally between ludicrous action scenes, some of them ripped off from better films.
Is it just me or is Charlie Sheen the kiss of death for anything other than Hot Shots?
This is the sort of film in which informants are shot in the head from across the street just as they are about to reveal the name of the traitor behind the scheme.
A truly pathetic thriller.
If you can't figure out all of the bad guys within the first ten minutes of the film, then you have not been getting your daily adult requirement of mysteries.
The audience is guaranteed to laugh at all the wrong moments.

Some political junkies have an inordinate yen for movies that hop-skip around familiar Washington, D.C., locales and inside the bowels of a sinister White House. Members of this club may get some ephemeral amusement out of Shadow Conspiracy.
The plot, as it eventually unfolds, is so absurd and leads to such a silly climax that much of the audience's good will is burned away.
The rest of the film is Sheen, playing a George Stephanopoulos-styled presidential adviser, being chased around Washington D.C. by an assassin who is a terrible shot and has no speaking lines.
Donald Sutherland plays Sheen's enigmatic mentor at the White House. Do you think he could have something to with the conspiracy? Sutherland as a bad guy? You think?
The betrayal, the chase scene, the narrow escape...all the ingredients are there, but they sit there flatly without the benefit of a single moment of imagination.
It's easy -- far too easy -- to use the title of Keenen Ivory Wayans' latest movie as a description. Unfortunately, it's also accurate.
Here is a movie about guns. Take away the guns, and the movie would be about nothing much.
Wayans isn't sure whether to send up Shaft and company or simply to remake the action thriller. The result is an embarrassing compromise.
I'm not sure what type of movie this is supposed to be or who its audience is, but it's a low down dirty shame that Wayans' talent is wasted on this film.
Unfortunately, however, where I'm Gonna Git You Sucka was completely off the wall, A Low Down Dirty Shame is just off.
Question of the day: why is there such an appeal to brainlessness?
The only people who could be surprised at this movie will be those who wandered into the wrong multiplex theater by mistake.
The In Crowd is one of those obscure features that a distributor sneaks into the summer marketplace when no one is looking.
The film showcases its attractive, scantily clad young cast, and ... well, I don't know what else, as there's nothing else there.
The more I think about it, the more I liked this movie. Not because it's good, but because it's enjoyably bad.
This is one crowd to avoid.
Brittany's badness is so fantastic that it's hard to care much whether she gets caught or if she kills her clueless prey or wins the useless Matt. Really, they all just deserve each other.
The In Crowd is way out of its depth.
Looks alone can't carry this mediocre drama/unsuccessful thriller hybrid that's clearly a dud.
Teen thrillers put style, naughtiness and tension ahead of characters and storyline, but every ship at least needs a hull, and this one's grounded before it even gets launched.
This college-age thriller is the second of two similarly themed movies this Spring about secret societies, with the other being The Skulls in February.
If you're looking for an engaging movie with complex characters and an intense storyline, then look elsewhere.
A glossy piece of trash.
Porno theater patrons who stumble into this pic purely for its endless landscape of girlie grillwork will get their money's worth.
As much as I did get into some of the story's original setup, I couldn't help but predict every coming moment as the film stepped forward.
Devoid of energy.
Crowd tries to be suspenseful, but fails to make sense.
The greatest mystery ... is how this thoroughly trashy picture wound up opening theatrically, rather than going direct to video where its sleazy assets might have been appreciated.
This movie features a lot of weak unknowns.
The In Crowd is a J. Crew ad gone very, very wrong.
Overall, pic feels cheap and by-the-book, with a dull, dark look and tech credits that seldom rise above the so-so.
So generic are the actors that you'll likely have trouble telling the dark-haired, handsome guys apart.
Besides bad writing and bad acting, the lighting is poor and the colors are faded.
There's no way I'll be able to explain all the cheesy goings-on in this one little note.
A teen screamer with enough implants for the boys and enough bitchiness for the girls to leave its target demographic lusting and screaming happily.
A thoroughly disposable psycho-thriller aimed at the teen demographic, and one of the very worst theatrical films of its type in recent memory.
It gives melodrama a bad name.
It's fairly slow-moving, and after a long buildup, the promised thrills never arrive.
Flees from anything that might involve real human emotion, or for that matter any credible human activity other than looking good.
Down to You is filled with all sorts of hokey moments that ruin its attempts to generate a pseudo-real, romantic atmosphere.
Crud of the lowest order.
Doesn't summon up quite enough quirky personality to maintain its momentum through the final act.
Call me old-fashioned, but I still think movies should have plots.
Delivers its cheesy toppings as predictably as the 30-minutes -or- it's-free pizza delivery guy.
Somewhere in all of that, there is a sweet story about two college kids who fall in love and find more than they are able to handle.

Playing a couple destined to be together by the last reel, Stiles and Prinze are up against it: there's not much tension in their fights or passion in their make-ups, mostly because their conclusion is so foregone.
In the great tradition of silly kids flicks -- the ones that are easier to dance to than get into.
Down to You is mildly worth watching for the performances if you don't get hung up on the cluttered plot.
The race for the year's worst film has begun.
Move on -- just move on.
Suffers from both a really bad set-up and a complete lack of a proper ending.
The acting never gets muscular enough to make the audience care about what happens.
They fall in love, break up, and fall in love again. The end.
This, then, is the death of the teen comedy.
Down to You ain't half bad.
I would rather suffer whiplash in a VW bug than sit through this film again.
Lamely written and directed.
Not really all that much fun.
An often endearing but largely botched attempt to put a more grown-up spin on the teen movie.
The inexperienced Isacsson's muddled stew of styles and story asides often leaves the movie flailing around like a dying fish.
You can smell the frying cheese from a mile away.
Probably more of a 'video movie' than anything else.
Watching talented young actors slowly committing career suicide is not a pretty sight.
Bland and uninviting.
Down to You is bad. Real bad.
Relies too much on gimmicky flashbacks and the quirkiness of the movie's supporting characters to compensate for the uninteresting leads.
Aimless!
It's only an outline for a typical boy meets girl story.
Down to You has cute boys, cute girls and little else.
Listless and sporadic.
The only way to stop the cinematic juggernaut known as the teen romantic comedy is for the target audience to come to its senses and stop supporting the darn things.
Made me tired of being a teenager.
There's little chemistry between co-stars Freddie Prinze Jr. and Julia Stiles.
Mediocre at best.
Woefully unamusing.
Writer/director Kris Isacsson, in his directorial debut, clearly has little confidence in the romantic 'A' story supporting his film.
Never rises above being merely skin-deep.
There's no real dramatic thrust.
We have a love story whose charm is often undercut by silly would-be comedy.
Down To You exists outside the realm of normal logic.

The shark models have so little movement that at times they seem to be supporting themselves on boats, instead of attacking them. Up until the ludicrous final sequence of the movie, the scariest creature in the film is an eel.
Significantly worse than the rest of the series, this film is one of the worst bell-flops in recent cinema.

After Steven Spielberg's original, which combined shock effects with comedy and grand sea adventure touches, the series has degenerated into your basic fish-bites-man story, with very few imaginative wrinkles.
Thrillseekers, this one's pretty dismal.
The only jaws to watch out for in this film are yours, hitting the floor.
Speed 2 can be numbered among the worst second chapters ever made.
I hope that somewhere Keanu Reeves is laughing about being considered a nonactor while the wax dummy Jason Patric has somehow achieved a rep as intense and gifted.
Movies like this embrace goofiness with an almost sensual pleasure. And so, on a warm summer evening, do I.
What a reeking bag of nothingness! What emptiness, what vaporous vapidity! What rot, stink, and whiff of mold spore!
It's still spring, but the films of this benighted summer can't get any worse than Speed 2, which demonstrates with shameless cynicism Hollywood's contempt for its audience.
There went two hours of my life that I shall never see again.
Bullock and Patric seem to be extremely good sports, given how little they have to work with (the film is clever, but strangely unengaging).
Speed 2 is a well-above-average armrest-gripper with little in it to upset the children excepting, perhaps, Dafoe's lengthy white teeth.
Speed 2 finds director De Bont and actor Bullock too content to coast on automatic.
It is exactly the type of movie that gives a bad name to sequels.
Even technically, the film has problems: unforgivable, given its massive budget.
It stays fun much longer than expected.
Not as bad as you might have thought it would be.
As the shipboard action erupts, so do several annoying movie clichs.
This one is so chaotic that it's hard to believe it was directed by Jan De Bont, even though he is perhaps to blame more than anyone else for the corruption of this genre.
A waterlogged sequel that'll soon be bottom-feeding with Beyond the Poseidon Adventure.
Just about as bad as they come.
They keep getting worse and worse and worse . . .
Bullock should be thinking about changing management.
The most un-called for sequel in recent memory.
Highlander 2: The Quickening is the most hilariously incomprehensible movie I've seen in many a long day -- a movie almost awesome in its badness.
Mulcahy and company don't ask us to suspend disbelief; they ask us to pretend we've all had weed-whacker lobotomies.
Ugh!
The acting is terrible,with Connery, at his lowest common denominator, stealing the show.
In short, lots of action and wild stunts, lame comedy and a story that makes no sense whatsoever.
It would be much more fun to see the film makers point fingers at each other over why this sequel is so bad.
One way to get through Baby Geniuses is to think about whether it really is the worst movie you've ever seen. Probably not, but pretty darn close.
I'll admit to chuckling a few times during the proceedings, but it's not worth losing 1 1/2 hours of one's life for a few minutes of amusement.
Bad films are easy to make, but a film as unpleasant as Baby Geniuses achieves a kind of grandeur.

The film is short -- so short that they tacked a sentimental little music video on the end and still it finishes in plenty of time for you to go find a real baby and appreciate the far more entertaining and exciting reality of babyhood.
shares with most of Clark's other films an utter lack of taste and a genuinely ugly look; not only is the movie less funny than a case of diaper rash, it's even less picturesque.
Easily one of the worst films in years.

This is a film so completely bankrupt of ideas that the last few minutes are composed entirely of short clips from elsewhere in the film...as if anyone would want to relive this travesty, even in the form of bite-sized none sequiturs.
This is a film for people with no taste.
Baby Geniuses is the best argument for stronger child labor laws since the Olsen twins.
Story? Who cares. Character development? That's for show-offs. Funny dialogue? Too hard to write. These babies can talk!!
Bob Clark's direction has no zing. And for a frantic comedy, there's surprising lack of energy.
Is it possible for a movie to be insulting from beginning to end, without pause at all along the way? As it turns out, yes indeed!
The target audience of Baby Geniuses is a mystery: the film is too inane for adults, too advanced for kids.
The film has a freak-show quality.
..absolute cinematic torture; a maniacal insult to the foundation that humanity is made upon...
The adult performers look genuinely embarrassed on screen. They should be. They might consider firing their agents.
Baby Geniuses doesn't waste any time getting stupid.
Cute but cloying -- unless you're really into watching the screen antics of two-year olds.
By the time the tiresome, surprisingly violent climax began, the last nail had already been hammered in this unfortunate film's coffin.
If you're a big Dennis Rodman fan, watch him playing basketball. If you're not, then you have zero reason to take in this movie.
One of the most awful movies (if you could even call it a movie) this year.
Me, I'll stick to appreciating Worm Rodman in his true and natural element: the 96-foot hardwood floor.
Mal actuada, mal editada, mal musicalizada y peor dirigida
With such sheer ineptitude onscreen it's amazing that this hack job didn't go straight to video.
And after about 20 minutes of this amateurish picture, extinction doesn't seem like such a bad idea.
Looking back on this film, I can't find anything nice to say about it.

If you're the kind of sci-fi fanatic who has to see every new futuristic action movie no matter how crummy it is then of course you'll check out Battlefield Earth regardless of how many cheap jokes critics crack at its expense.
A disaster of epic proportions.
It's generic sci-fi right down to the last detail.
This movie could not be stupider.
This Battlefield's girth is all flab, a bombastic concoction of miscued camp and underachieving action.

Battlefield Earth is just a lumbering, poorly photographed piece of derivative sci-fi drivel, full of grunting extras scampering around in animal pelts and more dank, trash-strewn sets than I ever care to see again.
John Travolta and Forest Whitaker do some Hollywood slumming in this tenement of a sci-fi thriller. (10-year-olds may enjoy.)
Is it as bad as advertised? Oh yes, very much so.
The characters are so deliciously absurd.
It's hard to say which is the most embarrassing moment in John Travolta's longtime dream movie of L. Ron Hubbard's 1982 novel.
Don't see this movie.
And you thought Dune was bad.
At about the one hour mark, a portion of the audience split the scene and I don't blame them. They were fed-up with being taken for complete and utter morons.

They brought it into existence, this hellbeast of a movie, this monstrosity, this slap in the face of all that is good and right and beautiful and sweet and gentle. Oh, the humanity! Hide the children's eyes!
Travolta and his fellow bad guy (played by Forest Whitaker) spend an inordinate amount of time cackling and showing off poor oral hygiene.
Remarkable mainly for rendering the prospect of human extinction inconsequential.
Now that it's finally on the screen, we discover that the science-fiction epic Travolta considered a Holy Grail is silly junk.
A pretty terrible film.
If you are the type of person who likes to watch traffic accidents, then this is for you.
Made with the misguided passion only true believers can muster, this adaptation of L. Ron Hubbard's novel can only (kindly) be described as a monumental folly.
Though the vast majority of our civilization has not survived, it's good to know that most of our clichs are alive and well in the year 3000.
to make matters worse, Earth only covers half of Hubbard's 1,000-plus page novel. The filmmakers plan on releasing a sequel in two years.
Didn't anyone stand up at a production meeting to say that the script is idiotic? That the movie steals unashamedly from countless other sci-fi movies?
Battlefield Earth is as relentlessly grim as it is artless, and Elia Cmiral's bombastic score also makes it painful to listen to.
A noisy, chaotic, sloppily edited and embarrassingly banal and derivative saga.

The movie is so outrageously, spectacularly, unbelievably bad that we stare at it with some sort of appalled curiosity. It fails on so many levels that it's fascinating, although not so much that I'd sit through it again.
Deeply dumb, depressingly derivative and just plain nonsense.
Simply put, Battlefield Earth is the worst film I've seen in over 10 years, and believe me, that's saying a lot.
Sitting through the summer's first monolithic monstrosity, Battlefield Earth, was one of the most painfully excruciating experiences of my life.
The movie plays like an uglier, Earth-bound Star Wars, interrupted by frequent Psychlo temper tantrums.
It's so unbelievably and egregiously bad, you have to wonder if they did it on purpose.
Bad science-fiction has a new name, and it is Battlefield Earth, the early frontrunner for this year's worst movie.
Battlefield Earth should be shown only at maximum-security prisons when a prisoner is tossed in solitary for bad behavior.
The words 'so bad it's good' strain to make themselves heard through the film's coarse bluster and grimy din.
This third-rate B-movie is predictable and silly in the extreme.
It was a helluva comeback, John. Now go away.
Is it worth seeing once? Sure.
If filmmaking has ever been less thrilling and more disengaging, I'd like to see it.
Battlefield Earth saves its scariest moment for the end: a virtual guarantee that there will be a sequel.
Battlefield Earth bathes in a pool of utter ridiculousness and cheesy visual styles, then stands up expecting everyone to admire it

The leader bares a resemblance to Andy Rooney of 60 Minutes, eyebrows and all. It would have been apropos for him to look into the camera and say, 'Don't you just hate it when you waste money on really stupid movies with cheesy special effects?'
I hated this movie, and I had a great time doing it.
It's probably obvious by now that Battlefield Earth is far from cerebral or anything even remotely serious.
Despite starting off like a bad Star Trek episode, this film eventually graduates to a higher level.
The first few moments of the film evoke heroism and noble struggle. After that, it's Grade A drivel.
Battlefield Earth is dumb.
It's been a while since we've seen dumb entertainment this unpretentious, so why worry that it doesn't make a lick of sense?
The dialogue is inane, the acting wooden.
Wooden acting, sappy melodrama and illogical plot lines.

Nothing wrong with borrowing from other movies. Except that the new piece needs some fresh energy to retool the old ideas and bring them back to life. And that is exactly what Battlefield Earth lacks.
Mish-mosh of dank dialogue and predictable plot.
Big-budget, little-intelligence entertainment.
Battlefield Earth is long and tedious.
So overwrought, overacted and overwhelmingly inept that it must be seen to be believed.
It's bombastic, chaotic, plodding, visually dreary and patchily written by first-timer Corey Mandell and JD Shapiro, who's too unimportant to rate mention in the press kit.
Battlefield Earth has the feel of a movie made by a precocious 8-year-old with access to too many leftover costumes from Clan of the Cave Bear and Star Trek: The Next Generation.
Battlefield Earth is a shrill, hollow and unintelligible movie with no redeeming value whatsoever.
In the post-apocalyptic adventure genre, Battlefield Earth makes Waterworld look like a masterpiece.
The narrative is unclear beyond this one fact: Apes control the planet and humans are their slaves. Oops. Wrong movie -- but not by much.
Younger, less discriminating viewers (5-year-old boys) will eat it up.
As it gets more loudly ludicrous, with destruction coming in vast waves, you don't think 'piece of cake' but 'piece of (oops).'
While the look is cool -- like a tinted B&W film, all washes of green, blue, amber and red -- the story's broad strokes are painfully clichd and its details make no sense at all.
Okay folks, we've got a winner for worst film of the year, and the year isn't even half over yet.
In Battlefield Earth, it`s all flash for no reason.
This is florid science fiction, low-brow but energetic, complete with cheesy thrills.
A truly dire and silly rehash of Planet of the Apes.
The plot depends on the most ludicrous decisions and senseless actions ever made by a thinking race.
Battlefield Earth begins as retro pulp and ends up, figuratively speaking, as tons of wet cardboard.
You don't watch it -- you survive it.
Even if you were to classify it as a guilty pleasure, it would be the kind of sullying guilt that makes people leap from heights.
The only people this film could recruit are members of the rock band Kiss, who, with their high-heeled boots and face paint, might figure they've got a spot if this alien thing ever really came down.
What this movie lacks in simple logic, it makes up for in its apparent unintentional campy humor.
It will no doubt take a place of honor in the proud pantheon of 'What Were They Thinking?' cinema, right alongside The Postman and Howard the Duck.
As for the allegation that this boring movie will recruit youth -- I doubt it!

Christian has chosen ... the sneaky trick ... of making ... the film ... so ... plodding ... that you'll leave ... the theater ... wondering ... whether ... 1,000 years ... have ... passed ... since ... you ... went ... in.

I cannot help but think that maybe [Travolta's] laughing that he was able to sucker people into pouring millions of dollars toward making such an unspeakable waste.

The first film had maybe a shred of realism to flavor its romantic comedy. This one looks like it was chucked up by an automatic screenwriting machine.
A crude and mawkish film in which dogs attempt to communicate with Kirstie Alley and John Travolta.
Although Tim Burton had nothing to do with it, this is certainly a nightmare before Christmas.
Most of the way this is pretty cheesy stuff, too stupid for adults and too vulgar for children. And it's even worse when it goes for cheap sentiment.

This is the kind of movie that isn't even worth renting when it comes out on video because, with the possible exception of Michael Lerner and Omar Epps dancing to show tunes, you've seen it all before.
Is it possible to try too hard without making any effort whatsoever? Because that seems to be the one slim accomplishment of The Mod Squad.
The Mod Squad has an intriguing cast, a director who knows how to use his camera and a lot of sly humor. Shame about the story.
The film starts out promising, but ends up forgetting its promises.
The lack of plot and lack of action are fatal flaws.
If the makers of the new Mod Squad had really studied their source material, they would have noticed how weak it was to begin with, and ended this mess after 60, rather than 94, minutes of pain.
You want everyone to be cool or at least cheesy-cool, but really, they end up looking waify and overwhelmed, not so much rebellious as fatigued.
Lame and lifeless.
I suspect this trio of actors -- more an Odd Squad than a Mod Squad -- will someday look back on this film as a forgettable footnote in hopefully more substantial careers.
Subject yourself to this mindless movie in quantities larger than 30 seconds, and you'll certainly regret it.
Witty and self-aware at times, but the story is lame.
Between the idea and the screen much can go amiss -- and in this case, it has.
The film has the look of a Levi's button-fly loose-fitting wide-legged baggy-crotch jeans commercial -- all edgy and alternative.
The Mod Squad is: 1. Sexy. 2. Cool. 3. Mod. 4. None of the above. 5. And then some!
The predictable result is a sketchy, half-baked, stylistically inconsistent movie that scarcely even pretends to care whether it makes sense or not.

Brainless, but enjoyably over-the-top, the retro gang melodrama, Deuces Wild represents fifties teen-gang machismo in a way that borders on rough-trade homo-eroticism.

It's tough to tell which is in more abundant supply in this woefully hackneyed movie, directed by Scott Kalvert, about street gangs and turf wars in 1958 Brooklyn -- stale cliches, gratuitous violence, or empty machismo.

full of attractive, listless actors who apparently couldn't get jobs on any of the WB's teen soap operas striking poses and mouthing dusty dialogue.

finds (Travolta) wobbling around in the highest platform shoes since Elton John and sporting bizarre dreadlocks... the oddest vanity production imaginable, one in which the main attraction is nearly impossible to recognize.

Nothing but a big, fat tease.

Both half-hearted and half-assed

Avoid.

A comedic train wreck that could very well make Carvey the next Joe Piscopo.
I really wanted to get up and walk out, but morbid curiousity held me in my seat to see if it ever got any better. It didn't. This blows beyond imagination.

A 75-minute sample of puerile rubbish that is listless, witless, and devoid of anything resembling humor.

Cruelly and brutally unfunny.
It's as if you're watching a movie that was made in 1978 but not released then because it was so weak, and it has been unearthed and released now, when it has become even weaker.
A jumbled fantasy comedy that did not figure out a coherent game plan at scripting, shooting or post-production stages.
The Master of Disguise is funny--not "ha ha" funny, "dead circus performer" funny. And for all the wrong reasons besides.

In a big corner office in Hell, Satan is throwing up his hands in surrender, is firing his R&D people, and has decided he will just screen The Master of Disguise 24/7.
This movie is filled with such nonsense.
Lack of a sympathetic main character is only one of the film's many faults.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: The Master Of Disaster - it's a piece of dreck disguised as comedy.
Dana Carvey's kid-friendly comedy about a "man of a thousand faces" has perhaps five laughs.
The Master of Disguise finds Carvey woefully out of practice.
This kiddie-oriented stinker is so bad that I even caught the gum stuck under my seat trying to sneak out of the theater
The Master of Disguise falls under the category of 'should have been a sketch on Saturday Night Live.'
The movie is a desperate miscalculation. It gives poor Dana Carvey nothing to do that is really funny, and then expects us to laugh because he acts so goofy all the time.
Neither [Carvey] nor semi-competent director Perry Andelin Blake have the ability to sustain a scene or idea.

Pity first-time filmmaker Perry Andelin Blake, who tries to make the best of this mess, despite being saddled with a star who seems to have no self-restraint, and who clearly has had his sense of what's funny and what's not seriously impaired.
A painfully unfunny mess.
Dana Carvey is slowly strangling his own legacy with an inane script and flatulence jokes that could've been written on the elementary school playground.

Despite all evidence to the contrary, this clunker has somehow managed to pose as an actual feature movie, the kind that charges full admission and gets hyped on TV and purports to amuse small children and ostensible adults.
An embarrassing mess for all involved, this so-called family comedy is about as unfunny as unfunny gets. Even its fart jokes are below the industry standard.
If you really want Carvey to make you laugh, you're better off watching an old SNL repeat. From the 1980s.
Master of Disguise runs for only 71 minutes and feels like three hours.

The Master of Disguise is full of jokes, but just about the only one that provokes widespread giggles from the short-pants set is the villain's tendency to have his maniacal laughing fits cut short by inadvertent toots of flatulence.
No one but a convict guilty of some truly heinous crime should have to sit through The Master of Disguise.
Only a human vegetable could have possibly viewed the final cut and not have had any vocal concerns about the submerged level of quality on display.
A calamitous attempt at reviving the anarchic, little-kid spirit of Jerry Lewis.

It's the one summer movie you simply can't afford to see.
Dana Carvey makes a lackadaisical 'comeback' as a man of a thousand faces, none of them funny.
[A] shapeless blob of desperate entertainment.
At times, it actually hurts to watch.

The only camouflage Carvey should now be considering is a paper bag to wear over his head when he goes out into public, to avoid being recognized as the man who bilked unsuspecting moviegoers.
Painfully unfunny and misguided to boot.
Lacking even a hint of humor or a watchable story, Disguise has distinguished itself as the summer's worst movie.
The only young people who possibly will enjoy it are infants... who might be distracted by the movie's quick movements and sounds.
The Master of Disguise is easily one of the worst movies of 2002.
Just another loop in Dana Carvey's shame spiral; a path that begins right where Wayne's World 2 ends.
There's no disguising this as one of the worst films of the summer. Or for the year, for that matter.
Despite its best intentions, Deuces Wild is an empty hand.

Not even a master of disguise can make this sloppy slapstick look like anything more than an incoherent cowpie of a comedy.
Adults may find this film as amusing as an old lady slipping on a banana peel.
This wretchedly unfunny wannabe comedy is inane and awful - no doubt, it's the worst movie I've seen this summer.

A franchise sinks in this sequel's endless sea of incompetence.
A gimmick in search of a movie: how to get Carvey into as many silly costumes and deliver as many silly voices as possible, plot mechanics be damned.
An unfunny waste of time.
so misconceived on every level, it's almost fascinating to watch. If you don't mind pain, that is. This movie knows how to make you hurt...
... The cinematic equivalent of the 8-year-old hooligan who mocks you by repeating everything you say.
Astonishing isn't the word -- neither is incompetent, incoherent or just plain crap. Indeed, none of these words really gets at the very special type of badness that is Deuces Wild.

Sadly, 'Garth' hasn't progressed as nicely as 'Wayne.'
Quite honestly, I've never seen anything less competent. And I mean that.

This pathetic junk is barely an hour long. Nevertheless, it still seems endless.
I cannot disguise my feelings - this film sucks.
I've always been a fan of Dana Carvey. How could someone so funny turn out a movie as pathetic as this?
An awful, stillborn comedy assembled out of rusty spare parts from secret agent movies and run-of-the-mill Saturday Night Live skits.

...it is definitely a come down to see the resilient comic attached to this excruciating, infantile flick. Conversely, Carvey needs to go incognito with the flaccid family fare The Master of Disguise

An insultingly bad movie, and even the flashiest, most distracting sound and visual gimmicks cannot hide this fact.
A road trip that will get you thinking, 'Are we there yet?'
In just over a minute you can see everything that's wrong with this one-joke farce.

A complete waste of time.

Though Perry and Hurley make inspiring efforts to breathe life into the disjointed, haphazard script by Jay Scherick and David Ronn, neither the actors nor director Reginald Hudlin can make it more than fitfully entertaining.
Skip this turd and pick your nose instead because you're sure to get more out of the latter experience.
Stars Matthew Perry and Elizabeth Hurley illicit more than a chuckle, and more jokes land than crash, but ultimately Serving Sara doesn't distinguish itself from the herd.
Serving Sara is the kind of movie that should premiere on an airplane--it's lame but watchable, and you could read a magazine during it and still follow the plot.
A supposed neo-screwball romp that ends up feeling like an episode of Friends set in Texas crossed with an Estee Lauder shoot.

Serving Sara is merely a serving of average, forgettable Hollywood fare.
With the dog days of August upon us, think of this dog of a movie as the cinematic equivalent of high humidity.

... Hudlin is stuck trying to light a fire with soggy leaves.

Serving Sara should be served an eviction notice at every theater stuck with it.

Serving Sara is fitfully funny but so threadbare in most respects that killing time is the only reason to see it.
With the exception of some fleetingly amusing improvisations by Cedric the Entertainer as Perry's boss, there isn't a redeeming moment here.
The script is clever enough to give Perry a somewhat dignified role as a sarcastic, educated charmer down on his luck.
Director Reginald Hudlin and screenwriters Jay Scherick and David Ronn never seem to have settled on a comic tone, with painfully uneven results.
Late summer is often the dumping ground for comedies that go flat or romances that fizzle. Sara is both.
Serving Sara is little more than a mall movie designed to kill time.
Surprisingly amusing.
[Hell is] looking down at your watch and realizing Serving Sara isn't even halfway through.
The jokes are telegraphed so far in advance they must have been lost in the mail.
The movie starts off embarrassingly bad. Ten one-liners go by with not even a smirk from the audience.
Don't waste your time with Serving Sara.
The film's original idea never gets fully exploited and is instead riddled with standard jokes and situations.
Too mucky and uneven to signify an out-and-out winner, but...charming when it wants to be and not nearly as bad as early word has suggested.

[A] poorly executed comedy.
...excruciatingly numb and mindless romantic comedy. There's nothing here that the main leads or supporting players can do to serve Sara her just desserts.

If you're looking for comedy to be served up, better look elsewhere.
A movie without a redeeming feature: a black hole where laughter goes to die.
The film is a disaster all around.
The plot is as exciting as a dead horse.
This mind-numbing comic void never generates enough electricity to brown an English muffin.
As a romantic couple, Perry and Hurley have all the chemistry of roadkill and a bran muffin.
I'm a little unclear as to how [the players] score points, but it has something to do with slamming a golf ball into a waffle-iron.
There are many definitions of 'time waster' but this movie must surely be one of them.
With Vicodin-sharp timing, Perry wavers from glib to glazed, seeming to openly rue his miscasting as palookaville process server Joe Tyler.
Perry's biting and bitter sarcasm helps fill the gaping holes left in the script by the studio weasels that digested it.
There are some fairly unsettling scenes, but they never succeed in really rattling the viewer.
A broadly played, lowbrow comedy in which the cast delivers mildly amusing performances and no farm animals were injured by any of the gags.
Scarcely worth a mention apart from reporting on the number of tumbleweeds blowing through the empty theatres graced with its company.

As scary and minor-chord heavy as FearDotCom can be, there's no big payoff, no logical resolution. It's like waiting for a site to download, only to find that when it happens, anticipation was more than half of the empty thrill.
Feardotcom's thrills are all cheap, but they mostly work.
fear dot com is so rambling and disconnected it never builds any suspense.
Summer's far too fleeting to squander on offal like this.
Anyone not into high-tech splatterfests is advised to take the warning literally, and log on to something more user-friendly.
If (this) sounds like entertainment to you, perhaps you should save the price of admission and put it toward therapy.
The only thing to fear about "Fear Dot Com" is hitting your head on the theater seat in front of you when you doze off thirty minutes into the film.
Expect to be reminded of other, better films, especially Seven, which director William Malone slavishly copies.
Press the delete key.
My greatest fear is watching a film that's so bad that it literally sucks the life right out of you, and I think this one came pretty close.
Despite the up-to-the-minute trappings, there's nothing here that's newer than rotary-dial phones.
The movie itself is a cattle ranch full of joke droppings and mooing shtick not worth stepping in.
It's a glorified sitcom, and a long, unfunny one at that.
The plot fluctuations unfold as predictably as any other cross-country buddy-buddy flick you care to mention.
The dialogue is witless, the situations are lame, the humor juvenile and the chemistry between the stars nonexistent.
Cinematic poo.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: The biggest fear I have is being tortured by having to watch this movie until my eyes and nose start bleeding.
The latest in a string of failed dot-com ventures.
Nonsensical, dull "cyber-horror" flick is a grim, hollow exercise in flat scares and bad acting.
Even the trickle of tit shots didn't do much for me.
Feardotcom invents a whole new kind of bad.
The screenplay is a mess, and yet the visuals are so creative this is one of the rare bad films you might actually want to see.
The only thing scary about feardotcom is that the filmmakers and studio are brazen enough to attempt to pass this stinker off as a scary movie.
The only thing you have to fear ... is being trapped in a theater showing this dot-bomb.
A vile, incoherent mess...a scummy ripoff of David Cronenberg's brilliant 'Videodrome.'
The only upside to all of this unpleasantness is, given its Labor Day weekend upload, FearDotCom should log a minimal number of hits.
This is a grim, ugly exercise that has nothing to say about the dangers of cyberporn.
It misses the big picture, the story is impossibly lame, but you can't say it doesn't have style.
It's tough to be startled when you're almost dozing.
What we get in FearDotCom is more like something from a bad Clive Barker movie. In other words, it's badder than bad.
This intensely derivative mishmash owes its creepiest images and conceits to other films.
With any luck, most moviegoers trying to log on to FeardotCom will find themselves confronted by a busy signal or an internal server error.
Going to the website may be just as fun (and scary) as going to the film.
You'd think Jeannie would be angry at mom for being so preposterously dim, but no, she's taking it out on people who surf the internet. You've been warned.
What could have been a pointed little chiller about the frightening seductiveness of new technology loses faith in its own viability and succumbs to joyless special-effects excess.
The film's storyline is so convoluted and contradictory that it's difficult to figure out what question the film is asking, let alone find the answer.
I'll go out on a limb. It isn't quite one of the worst movies of the year. It's just merely very bad.
A mess when it comes to the characters and writing...but works its way underneath the skin like few movies have in recent memory.

A prime example of just how bad a bad movie can be.
An awfully ridiculous horror film that thinks itself grandly mysterious and bone-shakingly horrifying.

All people involved in this movie should be served with papers demanding that they never collaborate on anything ever again.</
In a year that has given us some of the worst films of all time, this must surely rank as the worst -- and that's a hard thing to do opposite Master of Disguise.
Promise me you won't go there.
Two hours of sepia-tinted heavy metal images and surround sound effects of people moaning.
Intense, effective creepiness mated with inept, laughable policework - tragic to behold.

Taken purely as an exercise in style, this oppressively gloomy techno-horror clambake is impossible to ignore. But as a movie, it's a humorless, disjointed mess.
If it's not too late -- and, seriously, I hope it's not -- Hurley and Perry better clinch some more substantial roles quick, maybe even straight dramatics, because they're both capable.
It's not pretty watching this likable cast floundering in search of something funny to do.
A lackluster movie that is nonentheless extremely creepy, and made with a modicum of respect for an all too often disdained genre and its knowing fans.
Completely creatively stillborn and executed in a manner that I'm not sure could be a single iota worse... a soulless hunk of exploitative garbage.
Makes me yearn to use colloquial phrases like 'sucks big time' and 'piece of crap,' but, alas, I cannot bring myself to do so except with quotation marks.
Log on to my imaginary website: www.this-movie-sucks.com.
May just be the stupidest suspense thriller I have ever seen.

The movie's progression into rambling incoherence gives new meaning to the phrase 'fatal script error.'
Some fine European actors are caught slumming in this piece of glittery trash, including Stephen Rea (with a flat upstate accent), Udo Kier, and Nigel Terry. Now that's scary.

A 90 minute cacophony of bullets, bombs, and other things that go boom, delivered without the tiniest thread of excitement.
Why have a plot, characters, dialogue? Maybe the sequel will be called Simplistic: Bullets vs. Humans.
Spielberg should never have sold the sequel rights
Most new movies have a bright sheen. Some, like Ballistic, arrive stillborn... looking like the beaten, well-worn video box cover of seven years into the future.
It cannot be enjoyed, even on the level that one enjoys a bad slasher flick, primarily because it is dull. Yes, dull.
I accuse films of being generic and unoriginal on a regular basis, but rarely have I seen a movie so determined to check off every clich on the list as Deuces Wild.
