Rarely has such a talented comedian been so wildly out of touch with what's funny.
Kaos was apparently aiming for a coolly stylized, straight-faced take on Spy vs. Spy. As Maxwell Smart used to say, 'Missed it by that much.'
A shambles of a movie--visually unattractive, unbearably loud and utterly silly...its hilarity is completely unintentional.
Mindless and boring martial arts and gunplay with too little excitement and zero compelling storyline.
Gives new meaning to the word incoherent and provides as much excitement as my big ass.
I'd truly hoped that Ballistic would be a kicky so-bad- it's-good guilty pleasure. But it's too flat, stale, confusing and lazy.
Ballistic offers little beyond what you'd find in a typical subpar Hollywood action film.

While much of the film's action ... comes live, as opposed to the digital mayhem of the game, Thai director Kaos (a.k.a. Wych Kaosayananda), making his inauspicious Hollywood debut, still can't breathe any life into it.
Kaos has studied the John Woo playbook carefully -- using slow motion and spectacular shootouts and explosions -- but lacks the remarkable cutting that is a key part of Woo's work.
To the civilized mind, a movie like Ballistic: Ecks Vs. Sever is more of an ordeal than an amusement.
Eckstraordinarily lame and Severely boring.
One well-timed explosion in a movie can be a knockout, but a hundred of them can be numbing. Proof of this is Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever.
One of the most incompetent big-budget action movies I've ever seen.
...the film suffers from a lack of humor (something needed to balance out the violence)...
One of the worst action films of the year.
Exactly what you'd expect from a guy named Kaos.
For a film about explosions and death and spies, "Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever" seems as safe as a children's film. Well, in some of those, the mother deer even dies.
It hopes to obscure its awfulness with its volume and, failing that, it hopes to dress up its stupidity with backlit shots of a woman communing with a captive manatee.
If only Maxwell Smart had been here to foil KAOS yet again - avoid at all costs
There are two good things about Ballistic ... The rest of the movie, unfortunately, is all gaping narrative holes, uninspiring action scenes and repetitive slow-motion camerawork.
Ballistic is all over the map, a series of overwrought-yet -underachieving action set pieces punctuated by a muddled story line.
The action scenes have all the suspense of a 20-car pileup, while the plot holes are big enough for a train car to drive through -- if Kaos hadn't blown them all up.
For a movie with so much fire, this one totally lacks heat.
There's lots of fighting, which is a good thing because the action in this movie is better than the talk. But that isn't saying much.
This grim, joyless motion picture is anything but fun. It's a chore to sit through, with all the blazing, noisy pyrotechnics proving unable to lighten the mood.
It's loud and boring; watching it is like being trapped at a bad rock concert.
If you collected all the moments of coherent dialogue, they still wouldn't add up to the time required to boil a four- minute egg.
For a shoot-'em-up, Ballistic is oddly lifeless.
Spy-vs.-spy action flick with Antonio Banderas and Lucy Liu never comes together.
The film makers treat this movie like we already know the characters and they need no development.
So devoid of any kind of intelligible story that it makes films like XXX and Collateral Damage seem like thoughtful treatises

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: It's like going into a gunfight with a half-empty clip - it may seem okay in the beginning, but you aren't going to be happy with the results.
Kaos, the screenwriters and the actors occasionally seem to forget even the tiny handful of plot points that have been established, such as the names of the characters.
Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever is an ungainly mess, submerged in mayhem, occasionally surfacing for cliches.
The awkwardly titled Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever (try saying it 10 times fast) amply demonstrates how even a movie with wall-to-wall action can be a crashing bore.
Slow in a strange way -- without energy, without imagination, without urgency.

Connoisseurs of bad action-movie dialogue will delight in scenes that have "DIA" operatives, dressed in what look like black beekeeper outfits, racing about Vancouver with machine guns slung over their shoulders.
Ballistic: Ecks Vs. Sever has to be one of the worst films ever made. Sadly, you almost have to see it to believe it.
I'm guessing the director is a magician. After all, he took three minutes of dialogue, 30 seconds of plot and turned them into a 90-minute movie that feels five hours long.
...brainless, idiotic action, and somehow still not any fun.

"Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever" is one of those movies that you should see tucked away and the bottom of the New Release section in Blockbuster where all the other straight-to-video, Z-grade explosion flicks are kept.
Just plain silly.

Whether it's the worst movie of 2002, I can't say for sure: Memories of Rollerball have faded, and I skipped Country Bears. But this new jangle of noise, mayhem and stupidity must be a serious contender for the title.

In addition to sporting one of the worst titles in recent cinematic history, Ballistic: Ecks Vs. Sever also features terrible, banal dialogue; convenient, hole-ridden plotting; superficial characters and a rather dull, unimaginative car chase.
At best, Ballistic is a movie that wants to be a video game. At worst, it's a colossal waste of time.
Comic-book logic in action movies has seemingly given way to video-game logic which is almost no logic at all and spooling out Ballistic's inane, convoluted plot is a waste of time.
A fine achievement in stupidity and dullness despite plenty of explosions.
The movie may be called Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever, but it could've been called Audience vs. Dozing Off.
Two big things are missing -- anything approaching a visceral kick, and anything approaching even a vague reason to sit through it all.
The film is bad on just about every level.
The reunion scene between Ecks and his wife is seat-squirmingly awful. It's one of the few moments where there isn't an explosion, and where we really could've used one.
Kaos has promise as a visual stylist, but this movie has no story or characters.
Some movies were made for the big screen, some for the small screen, and some, like Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever, were made for the palm screen.
For years, people have joked about an action movie that might eliminate plot altogether and simply cut to the pyrotechnics. Someone has finally done it.
Almost completely uninvolving, as well as being impenetrable.
Enough to make a critic go ballistic.
It's tempting to compare Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever to a video game, but that would be giving it credit for more substance and coherence than it deserves.
A loud, incoherent piece of action-movie overkill.

As fun as talking babies were, the buck stops here with talking dogs. Gone is the witty humour and sexual innuendo of the first film, and in it's place is a script just ripe for any 8 year old, but stale to anyone in the double digits.
The story would qualify as your basic spy opera... if there was any feeling to it, but the film has no more engagement than a big-screen video game
It's hard to imagine a more generic action film or a movie so wholly devoid of personality.
Horrendously amateurish filmmaking that is plainly dull and visually ugly when it isn't incomprehensible.
Never has sound and fury signified so little.
This is a forgettable picture, with the sad fact that with a little more effort and a veteran's hand, this film could've easily been a more compelling distraction.
Once again this shows that whilst the internet is a great way to promote films, its not something which films should base their stories on.
A truly lightweight forgettable piece of fluff which will barely make a blip either in the cinemas or on video.
Pay good money to see Ballistic: Ecks Vs. Sever and you have nobody but yourself to blame.
It's dreadful!
One of the worst movies of the year.
The title - insipid as it is - is more interesting than anything that actually appears on screen.
Maybe you'll be lucky, and there'll be a power outage during your screening so you can get your money back.
... After 90 minutes of mind-numbing explosions, I cheered when a death by electrocution finally broke the monotony.
Boring to an amazing degree -- considering that it's barely 90 minutes long and virtually nonstop gunfire, explosions and car crashes.
It's not always easy to tell what's going on in this movie which has all the emotional depth of a video game, and the dramatic coherence we associate with the lesser works of Ed Wood.
[Cedric the Entertainer] gives what just might be the worst performance of the year (and no, I'm not forgetting A Walk to Remember's Mandy Moore).
Its murky settings, contemptuous plotting and charmless characters add up to a film in which nothing counts more than death, preferably a spectacularly fiery death.
Even by dumb action-movie standards, Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever is a dumb action movie.
This movie is bad enough to make you want to go ballistic on Hollywood.
The Master of Disguise represents Adam Sandler's latest attempt to dumb down the universe.
Is "Ballistic" worth the price of admission? Absolutely not. It sucked. Would I see it again? Please see previous answer.
A depraved, incoherent, instantly disposable piece of hackery.
Yes, Ballistic is silly. Unfortunately, it's not silly fun unless you enjoy really bad movies.
One of the dumbest, least entertaining films I've seen this year.
The result is the equivalent to a roller coaster missing pieces of its track.

At every opportunity to do something clever, the film goes right over the edge and kills every sense of believability... all you have left is a no-surprise series of explosions and violence while Banderas looks like he's not trying to laugh at how bad it
Who, exactly, is fighting whom here? Ah, yes, that would be me: fighting off the urge to doze.
By the time the show ended I was laughing pretty hard just thinking about how the movie made no sense while it was trying to be so serious.
It's a deluge of bullets and chop-socky madness devoid of style or purpose.
Rank it up there amongst the true wastes of time Hollywood has ever foisted upon an unsuspecting public.
You'll have more fun setting fire to yourself in the parking lot. You'll be more entertained getting hit by a bus.

Build some robots, haul 'em to the theatre with you for the late show, and put on your own Mystery Science Theatre 3000 tribute to what is almost certainly going to go down as the worst -- and only -- killer website movie of this or any other year.
There's still something vaguely enjoyable about the film, as there has been with most of Matthew Perry's movies.
The film's only laughs come when Pistachio is off the screen, and dressed as someone else.
Actually, not as bad as the reviews say; still "solidly average" does not a red tomato buy.

As directed by William Malone, the man who nailed the "condemned" sign to the front of 1999's "The House on Haunted Hill," "Feardotcom" is essentially a showcase for the humiliation, mutilation and sadomasochistic torture of women.
A film substantially lacking in personality, energy, magic and humor.
Just too absurd to pay full price to see in a theater.
...The makers of Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever [take] so many of our favorite things and [make] such a wretched movie out of them.
Even if FearDotCom wasn't a good five years behind the curve, it would still be saddled with a ludicrous script, nonsensical direction and wince-inducing performances.
A bad movie that could have been a lot better if it had been a little bit worse.
The whole thing is so vague and preposterous and paranoid that it almost goes without saying that Donald Sutherland plays a key role.
It's painful to see Mr. Dafoe, an excellent actor, reduced to a snarling mad dog who treats his fatal disease -- copper poisoning? -- with leeches and spouts lines like ''Now you're gonna get it!''
The first big-screen resurrection aimed squarely at a generation that probably never heard of, much less watched, the original TV show.
Ballistic is a generic blur of metallic blue and fireball orange set to the contrapuntal sounds of throbbing techno and eardrum-puncturing noise.
There's nothing surprising about it, but aficionados of speed, quick cuts and high-tech mayhem will love John McTiernan's direction here. Oh, and there are way cool cars too.
Spectacularly awful film that's actually funnier than many so-called comedies.
A mix of velocity and idiocy, this ruinous remake lacks the brawn -- and the brains -- of the 1970s original.
By the genre's most basic standards, [Seagal] now displays a visible fatigue and lack of interest that proves deadlier than any of his hero's skills.

The first half of the movie ... is extraordinarily lame as the preposterous setup takes forever and actors go through the motions. But when the action finally kicks in, the film takes on a B-movie vitality that pulls the viewer in.
It's no use: At this point, the bloated action figure [Seagal] couldn't restore his street cred if he joined the Wu-Tang Clan.
The title of Half Past Dead isn't meant to describe the state of one-note, whisper-tough action star Steven Seagal's movie career -- but it wouldn't be far off.
It has more in common with a fireworks display than a movie, which normally is expected to have characters and a storyline.
Another thing that was painful to watch was the slow-motion.
Could as easily have been called 'Under Siege 3: In Alcatraz'...a cinematic corpse that never springs to life.
Hip-hop prison thriller of stupefying absurdity.
This is an action movie with an action icon who's been all but decommissioned.
Just like every other Seagal movie, only louder and without that silly ponytail.
Dreary and misogynistic.

A puffy-faced Steven Seagal, as an undercover Fed posing as a convict, ties on a doo-rag, exchanges longing buddy-movie glances with a couple of jaunty rap artists (Ja Rule and Kurupt) and goes lumbering off to battle.
The best thing about Half Past Dead is that its title provides an accurate description of how you will feel after watching it.
Every so often a film comes along that is so insanely stupid, so awful in so many ways that watching it leaves you giddy. Half Past Dead is just such an achievement.
Doesn't deliver a great story, nor is the action as gripping as in past Seagal films.
There's absolutely nothing of value here, and it's incredibly offensive to boot.
Absent one original moment and bathed in de rigueur steel blue punctuated by sporadic bursts of flaming orange, the movie is notable only for its creative approach to Seagal's bulky gracelessness.
Just to clear up any possible confusion, the title actually refers to Steven Seagal's latest action film, not his gasping-for-air film career.

After several scenes of this tacky nonsense, you'll be wistful for the testosterone-charged wizardry of Jerry Bruckheimer productions, especially because Half Past Dead is like The Rock on a Wal-Mart budget.

[Segal’s] rising age and weight increasingly render him implausible in the action-figure role. As for Ja Rule and the other convicts, they’re about as dangerous as a schoolyard game of cops and robbers.
Ja Rule and Kurupt should have gotten to rap. It would have benefitted the dialogue.
Don Michael Paul uses quick-cuts, (very) large shadows and wide-angle shots taken from a distance to hide the liberal use of a body double (for Seagal).

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: It would have been better if Seagal had signed a 'do not resuscitate' waiver.
It goes through the motions of an action thriller, but there is a deadness at its center, a feeling that no one connected with it loved what they were doing.
It's a trumped-up bit of nonsense that goes nowhere.
Has the cheesy, deadened feel of a straight-to-cable film.
Action/adventure dud.
A shoot-'em-up for cynical times. Its only asset is Seagal himself, and frankly, he's is getting a bit past it.
Has enough gun battles and throwaway humor to cover up the yawning chasm where the plot should be.
Seagal, who looks more like Danny Aiello these days, mumbles his way through the movie.
About as original as my last date's excuse for not wanting to go out with me anymore ('It's not you, it's me.')
Wildly incompetent but brilliantly named Half Past Dead -- or for Seagal pessimists: Totally Past His Prime.
Features nonsensical and laughable plotting, wooden performances, ineptly directed action sequences and some of the worst dialogue in recent memory.
It's loud, preposterous and mindless, but it rushes headlong like some runaway train mowing down action cliches along the way.
Seagal is bloated and puffy and still the worst actor among all the big action stars.
There is an almost poignant dimension to the way that every major stunt Seagal's character ... performs is shot from behind, as if it could fool us into thinking that we're not watching a double.
Ear-splitting exercise in formula crash-and-bash action.
A rip-off twice removed, modeled after [Seagal's] earlier copycat Under Siege, sometimes referred to as Die Hard on a boat.
Bang! Zoom! It's actually pretty funny, but in all the wrong places.
About as weak a movie as can be made without actively trying.
While action fans might find some of the fight sequences and related material to their non-discriminative liking, there's nothing here that you haven't seen or that's been done better before.
When Seagal appeared in an orange prison jumpsuit, I wanted to stand up in the theater and shout, 'Hey, Kool-Aid!'
Divertingly ridiculous, headbangingly noisy.
The entire movie is so formulaic and forgettable that it's hardly over before it begins to fade from memory.
First-time director Don Michael Paul can't make the action move, though he wisely keeps the lighting dark and murky so we can barely see whether withering star Seagal really can keep up.
Here, common sense flies out the window, along with the hail of bullets, none of which ever seem to hit Sascha.

If the title is a Jeopardy question, then the answer might be "How does Steven Seagal come across these days?" or maybe "How will you feel after an 88-minute rip-off of The Rock with action confined to slo-mo gun firing and random glass-shattering?

I'm afraid you won't get through this frankly fantastical by-the-numbers B-flick with just a suspension of disbelief. Rather, you'll have to wrestle disbelief to the ground and then apply the chloroform-soaked handkerchief.
Du grand grand vide que le nombre d'explosions n'arrive pas √† camoufler.
No, I don't know why Steven Seagal is considered a star, nor why he keeps being cast in action films when none of them are ever any good or make any money.
Uneven and inconsistent, but still, very amusing, good shoot-'em-up fun.
Remember when Steven Seagal made good action movies? I do.
The film has all the depth and subtlety of a Stephen J. Cannell (who makes a cameo appearance) television series, aspiring no higher than an episode of The A-Team or Hunter.
Seagal is painfully foolish in trying to hold onto what's left of his passe' chopsocky glory.
Paul shamelessly guides his film through the motions, without any idea that what he is committing to film here is beyond played out.
This is so bad.
Has not so much been written as assembled, Frankenstein-like, out of other, marginally better shoot-em-ups.
Corny, nonsensical buddy flick.
[Seagal's] strenuous attempt at a change in expression could very well clinch him this year's Razzie.
Almost dead on arrival.
Mindless mayhem.
Seagal ran out of movies years ago, and this is just the proof.
A film which proves 'more' means most certainly 'less' and like a video game its definitely not worth spending more than a few cents on.
The film's stagecrafts are intimate and therefore bolder than the otherwise calculated artifice that defines and overwhelms the film's production design.
Seagal has too much screen time and when he's on it, he takes up too much space.
... one of the worst prison movies made.
[Director Kris Isacsson] tries to bring a little enterprise to the inevitable scenes of bickering and moody silence, but by now the vitalising tactics seem out of place.
It doesn't help that the film's premise, which sees stoneage cavemen turn into ace fighter pilots with only a week's training, is as naive as that of the 1939 serial Buck Rogers.
Most of the action setups are incoherent.
I have to sit through it; it's my job. You don't.
I'd encourage you to avoid this bad comedy at all costs.
The way the action is shown here, it's an incoherent mess.
Such a brain dead, jukebox of a movie, it should've been called Tron for Dummies.
There really is no reason to see this film at all. Not even some of the cool, creepy imagery saves it.
Talk about a dot com failure.
With a couple of plot twists and a few powerful performances, Deuces Wild is worth checking out -- but only on home video.
I kept thinking Jay and Silent Bob would pop out and make a Star Wars joke.
I have no problem with the fact that [Seagal] doesn't use a Russian accent (Do they ever?), but he looks out of shape and tired.
There was no advance screening for this movie, so I actually had to pay to see this one myself. Don't make my mistake, because I'll never see that eight dollars ever again!
You know, usually I expect the studios to dump all their cinematic turds in January but, man, it's March already and I'm still sitting through this stuff.
AAAAAAAAGHHHH! MY EYES! IT BURNS! IT BURNS!
Add another one to the scrap heap of trendy, nostalgic, 60's and 70's TV shows reduced to cinematic rubble by the inspiration starved minds in Hollywood.
You'll have to be a cryptologist to figure out who's working for whom, and you'll have to boast the patience of Job to care.
A story that might be enacted by a deranged and sexually confused 12-year-old girl with her Barbie dolls
Lethal for kids and an unspeakable insult to adults, this unreleasable fiasco is a torture for all.
The rollerball sequences feel sanitised and stagey.
If it's another regurgitated action movie you're after, there's no better film than Half Past Dead.
[Trots] out the same tired cliches -- unorthodox heroes, inept commanding officers, officious little weasels getting trampled by the zany crew -- which haven't been funny since...well, ever.
Never have so many jokes clunked off the screen to such a silent audience. And never has 80 minutes seemed like such an eternity.
Here's hoping Benigni doesn't try to tackle The Little Mermaid as his next project.
A movie so bad that it quickly enters the pantheon of wreckage that includes Battlefield Earth and Showgirls.
Benigni's folly...In every sense of the word, the picture is just frightful; it will either terrify children or bore them to tears, and adults will be rightly appalled by it.

As the wooden puppet who yearns to be human, Benigni ... is steadfastly insufferable, from his naughty, nave stage through a transformation to a state of virtue that is steeped in a self-congratulatory martyrdom and nobility.
No matter how much he runs around and acts like a doofus, accepting a 50-year-old in the role is creepy in a Michael Jackson sort of way.
The movie unfolds in a clumsy zone between fantasy and realism, and in the end it's neither here nor there.
The idea of 49-year-old Roberto Benigni playing the wooden boy Pinocchio is scary enough. The reality of the new live-action Pinocchio he directed, cowrote and starred in borders on the grotesque.
Benigni's Pinocchio is extremely straight and mind-numbingly stilted, its episodic pacing keeping the film from developing any storytelling flow.
Even with its $50-million US budget, Pinocchio never quite achieves the feel of a fanciful motion picture.
Visually sumptuous but intellectually stultifying.
The only way this Pinocchio can have a fairy-tale ending is if you leave in time to get your money back; then you might live happily ever after.
Best described as slipshod, annoying and quite simply, shockingly bad.
Utterly lacking in charm, wit and invention, Roberto Benigni's Pinocchio is an astonishingly bad film.
In the spirit of the season, I assign one bright shining star to Roberto Benigni's Pinocchio -- but I guarantee that no wise men will be following after it.

It's a great, resonant comic premise, yet the film fails on every level, partly due to Carvey's charmless passive-aggressive manner - lacking the abrasive edge of Lewis or Adam Sandler, he's nakedly winsome, a puppy yapping for love.
Something must have been lost in the translation.
Absolutely (and unintentionally) terrifying.
I can easily imagine Benigni's Pinocchio becoming a Christmas perennial. Coal isn't as easy to come by as it used to be and this would be a worthy substitute for naughty children's stockings.
At times, the movie looks genuinely pretty. Your nightmares, on the other hand, will be anything but. Not even Felinni would know what to make of this Italian freakshow.
What makes the dub particularly egregious is the fact that Italy has entered Pinocchio as its contender for the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar, and we don't get to hear that foreign language.
What little atmosphere is generated by the shadowy lighting, macabre sets, and endless rain is offset by the sheer ugliness of everything else.

The art direction is often exquisite, and the anthropomorphic animal characters are beautifully realized through clever makeup design, leaving one to hope that the eventual DVD release will offer subtitles and the original Italian-language soundtrack.
About as cutting-edge as Pet Rock: The Movie.

With Danilo Donati's witty designs and Dante Spinotti's luscious cinematography, this might have made a decent children's movie -- if only Benigni hadn't insisted on casting himself in the title role.
Would Benigni's Italian Pinocchio have been any easier to sit through than this hastily dubbed disaster?
Even Pinocchio himself would pan this flick.
Audiences can be expected to suspend their disbelief only so far -- and that does not include the 5 o'clock shadow on the tall wooden kid as he skips off to school.
The so-inept- it's-surreal dubbing (featuring the voices of Glenn Close, Regis Philbin and Breckin Meyer) brings back memories of cheesy old Godzilla flicks.
Though boasting sumptuous production design, this redundantly plotted vanity project sadly lacks magic or charm.
While Benigni (who stars and co-wrote) seems to be having a wonderful time, he might be alone in that.
An epic turkey, in a league with this year's Swept Away, that must be seen to be believed.
Instead of hiding Pinocchio from critics, Miramax should have hidden it from everyone.
I can't say this enough: This movie is about an adult male dressed in pink jammies.
What remains is a variant of the nincompoop Benigni persona, here a more annoying, though less angry version of the irresponsible Sandlerian manchild, undercut by the voice of the star of Road Trip.
What can one say about a balding 50-year-old actor playing an innocent boy carved from a log?
Chalk it up as the worst kind of hubristic folly.
If you saw Benigni's Pinocchio at a public park, you'd grab your kids and run and then probably call the police.
It's a frightful vanity film that, no doubt, pays off what debt Miramax felt they owed to Benigni.
Adults will certainly want to spend their time in the theater thinking up grocery lists and ways to tell their kids how not to act like Pinocchio. As for children, they won't enjoy the movie at all.
Seriously, rent the Disney version.
In this case, a viewer's apathy to images of suffering and degradation are not a pointed comment on contemporary desensitization to violence -- it's just the proper response to a really crappy movie.
The dialogue is very choppy and monosyllabic despite the fact that it is being dubbed.
Despite delivering a sexy Rebecca Romijn-Stamos, this 5-mph trainwreck is a badly executed attempt at action that can't even be relied upon to deliver mindless and gratuitous violence.
Lucy Liu has the silent, exotic, Asian assassin thing down cold in a lackluster action movie with aimless fighting, wimpy villains, and a lame techno soundtrack.
Of all the trash I had to watch in 2002, the insipid FearDotCom easily ranks among the worst.
A corpse in its own right: It's filled with the rotting ideas of far better movies.
Here's a stretch: Elizabeth Hurley is a sexy English girl and Matthew Perry is Chandler in this senseless, surprisingly unfunny comedy.
Pushes the Hollywood action movie to stratospheric new levels of incoherence.

The director, William Malone, is like his villain: a sick person trying to justify what he's doing by making his audience voyeurs. He's like the character from Fight Club that splices hard-core porn into Disney films.
Benigni presents himself as the boy puppet Pinocchio, complete with receding hairline, weathered countenance and American Breckin Meyer's ridiculously inappropriate Valley Boy voice.
Sure, horror movies are supposed to be dark, but come on! Turn on a lamp sometime.
This is a serious contender for the title of The Worst Film Ever Made.

In the dire The Master of Disguise, Carvey is seen to maximum disadvantage as a dim-witted Italian-American waiter whose family have an inherited gift for turning themselves into anyone from Bo Derek to George Bush.
It is cut with all the precision and timing of an irritating kids' TV show, with kids themselves in charge of the production, and their pets operating the equipment.

Kaosayananda's approach to this thunderous and over-indulgent stylish stinker is quite simplistic: load up on excessive explosions that's meant to give a personality to a straining and exceedingly moronic martial arts motion picture.
When appreciating the heuristic nature of the hackneyed Fear Dot Com, do yourself a favor and be sure to log off immediately in reference to this misguided nightmarish nonsense.
This overproduced piece of dreck is shockingly bad and absolutely unnecessary. Hmmm...might I suggest that the wayward wooden one end it all by stuffing himself into an electric pencil sharpener?
It's hard to determine exactly where I gave up on Down to You, but I'm pretty sure it was right after the opening credits.
Clark has made several terrific films, this is not one of them.
Antonio Banderas, Lucy Liu, have you no pride? Have you no standards? Have you no shame? Don't you pay attention to what's written on the papers you're signing?
...So caught up in its own art it rarely succeeds at being truly scary.
If this film were just written badly, or just acted badly, it might have some value. But here we have a double negative.
This is an example of a sequel just as terrible as the first movie: same stuff, different day.
Thanks to computers, we have seen some dazzling special effects in films lately, but even the best medicines can have unwanted side effects.
This film maintains a surprising consistency of bad acting and directing almost from the first frame to the last.
...Designed to appeal to moviegoers whose goal is to sit in an air-conditioned theater for 1 1/2 hours with their brains on 'pause.'
Writer Scott Silver also directed the film, but obviously had no idea how to convey to his actors any sense of enthusiasm or energy.
...Occasional moments of Carvey genius (many of which are seen in the trailer) sprinkled sparsely throughout a senseless, leaden production...
t's obvious that Paul put more focus and energy into the film's visuals than into the story.
Wonder wheel! Pryor at his comedic best!
"Feardotcom" has the makings of an interesting meditation on the ethereal nature of the internet and the otherworldly energies it could channel, but it simply becomes a routine shocker.

What's most incredible is not that Benigni thought that he could pull off a believable wooden puppet who wants to be a boy, nor thet he could turn such a charming story into such a horrifically scary tale, but that the people of Italy love this movie so m
Some of Seagal's action pictures are guilty pleasures, but this one is so formulaic that it seems to be on auto-pilot.
I like dogs, but this movie is almost bad enough to be one.
The movie doesn't even work as a vehicle for Ja Rule, who's perfectly likable but gets lost in the hullabaloo of helicopter crashes, hostage negotiations, and assault weapons.
This is the stuff of good, clean, campy fun. But instead of titillating, The In Crowd is nothing but a deadly dull business.
Call it Dude, Where's My Horse?
A guilty pleasure more entertaining than the original
Here's yet another deafening, preposterous action movie created for extremely undemanding audiences that don't care about logic and coherence.

Sandra Bullock is as winning as usual and Willem Dafoe has great fun chewing up the scenery as the villain. Unfortunately, there's not much chemistry between Bullock and Patric, so the love story doesn't work.
The sets are laughably cheap, and the aliens look like geeks from a Star Trek convention who couldn't afford to buy the "good" Klingon costumes
An embarassment to all involved
I'm still clawing out my eyes.
The words 'directed by Sylvester Stallone' say it all.
Incredible ineptitude, a terminally shaky camera and plotholes you could drive the universe through.
Literally has to be the worst 'event' film ever made.
One of the worst films of 2002.
An own-goal fest that will have you asleep in your seat by half time.
Once upon a time Seagal's fighting made him look pretty deadly. These days he's looking way past dead.
Not exactly a storyline for the ages, is it? In fact, the plot seems so whisper-thin that you're barely aware of it as you watch the film.
Every good actor needs to do his or her own Hamlet. For Benigni it wasn't Shakespeare whom he wanted to define his career with but Pinocchio. It might as well have been Problem Child IV.
A flawed fraud, a youth movie so disjointed, witless and condescending that it's painful to watch.
Waaay too much like hard labour.
Forgive them, Lord; Russell et al know not what they do.
A dizzying array of badly edited action snippets give the impression of excitement, but only add to the confusion.
If this is what we have to look forward to in the year 3000, count me out.
Oblique revival of the The Bad Seed universe. [Full review in Spanish]
Wanton gunfire and witless good guys saturate this sadly scripted waste of hard-earned movie money.
For some reason, the movie's sex scenes, which are relatively few, have been directed as slapstick.
It's not easy to fathom how Mr. Selleck or any other actor could have read this far in Robert Klane's screenplay and still decided to go full steam ahead.
The film is so contemptuous of its audience it doesn't even bother to present a surface resemblance to reality.
It's absolutely worthless nonsense that's almost bad enough to make me wish cinema had never been invented.
Half Past Dead translated from Latin means 'Die Hard in a prison,' or so the filmmakers must have believed.
Mr. Wayans is an agreeable screen presence, but he makes a surprisingly bland action hero.

one of the least satisfying thrillers in years

No one associated with the film tries very hard, from cinematographer Peter Deming -- San Francisco has never looked so drab -- to composer Mark Isham, whose watery jazz score is meant to summon melancholy but merely relieves insomnia.

succeeds only in making one of Willis' previous bombs, HUDSON HAWK look, well, not good, nothing in this part of the time/space continuum can do that, but downright competent

The zany hitman action-comedy sequel that nobody asked for -- and yes, in case you're wondering, it's every bit as nonsensical and overitalicized a mess as The Whole Nine Yards.
It's not a movie made because someone had a good idea for how to follow up the funny first film - it's just a sequel for the sake of a sequel.
Why do filmmakers persist in making sequels to movies nobody seems to have liked in the first place, let alone loved with the kind of passion that leaves them hungry for more?
The original may not have offered a full nine yards of laughs, but the comedic value of this moronic sequel would have to be measured not even in inches, but in millimeters.
lacks any sort of coherent style
Though still fun, silly and occasionally very funny, the sequel falls a few inches short of 'The Whole Nine Yards.'
Unlike 'Gigli', this one is so embarrassingly unfunny that it probably will not evoke even an unintentional laugh.
If you're not familiar with the first film, most of the jokes and characters in this new outing will be meaningless to you.
The story is a formulaic jumble, and the minor characters often appear to have wandered in from another Hollywood set.

Marginally better directed and better written than the original Nine Yards, it's still a big, empty picture full of star turns, artificial energy and jokes that don't quite work, even if stars Willis and Perry do their best to slam them across.
Perry is good at physical comedy. But there are only so many times Oz can take pratfalls before we start to feel embarrassed for Perry for having to milk laughs from such feeble fodder.
The big surprise -- the only gratifying surprise -- of The Whole Ten Yards is that we're glad to see almost everyone back.
Where the first pic breezed along with gags and gunplay, this forced follow-up is artificial to the hilt -- fueled on a kind of trying-too-hard hilarity that makes even good actors look bad.
The strain needed to extend The Whole Ten Yards a yard -- and to feature length -- is so evident it breaks new pic's comedy spirit, making it a dubious member of the Sequel Hall of Shame.
...like a morgue for laughs. Dead jokes are lined up across the screen.

Strenuously unfunny.
An exercise in humiliation for all concerned.
[A] miserably unfunny, wholly unnecessary affair.
A disastrously unfunny sequel.
The sequel to The Whole Nine Yards is more afterthought than accomplishment, a cocktail made with orange juice and Champale instead of actual bubbly.
Ten Yards regathers the cast of quirky killers and neurotic nebbishes and gives them almost nothing to do.
Could it BE any more atrocious?
None of it is funny. At all. Not even a little.
Avoid the film, burn $10, down a large Coke, then jump up and down on your bed until you're completely nauseous. The effect will be the same but you'll save 90 minutes.
The only thing to keep this effort from sinking completely, like a snitch with cement shoes, is Kevin Pollack's broad portrayal.
If you want more of the same, Whole Ten Yards gives exactly that. And only that.
An excruciating rehash that has virtually none of the wit and charm of the original.
Here's another major-studio comedy that makes you want to apply for frequent-misery mileage.

one of the sloppiest pieces of hackwork to be put out by a major studio recently. In fact, this flaccid comedy's only laughs come from its sheer ineptitude.
A paltry collection of lame one-liners, stock characters and tired sight gags.
...fails to go the same distance its predecessors did in storytelling and, just like the title's dubious twist on the common expression, no one seems to know what it means.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: A recycled, unfunny, dumbed-down version of a really good movie - maybe a dose of that nitrous oxide would have helped .
It's merely there because Hollywood has turned into a boring, ol' risk-averse, churn-'em-out machine that'd rather bang out recycled garbage than take a chance on anything original.
The Whole sequel is so excruciatingly bad it reaches a new low for Bruce Willis.
If you find yourself pulled in with the Friday night herd to see the movie, you should be in for a tolerable enough time.
The extra yard in the title is, apparently, the amount of rope necessary for this unwanted franchise to hang itself.
[T]he perfect example of the utterly unnecessary sequel.
Willis gives head cases a bad name, never quite letting even his fellow actors in on the joke that he took this particular job for the paycheck.
Making a sequel to a forgettable little film released four years ago is bad enough, but The Whole Ten Yardsactually requires you to remember the first movie's plot.
It's yet another sequel that's just not as good as the original.
Nowhere amidst all the frantic clutter do we find anything resembling the sweet, nutty playing that elevated The Whole Nine Yards.
A redundancy that should more honestly be called The Whole Nine Yards All Over Again.
A dumb, pointless sequel.
On a 1-to-10 scale of bad comedy (10 being the unfunniest), this one rates an 11.
If The Whole Nine Yards was a by-product of the hit man genre of dark comedies launched by Quentin Tarantino and Pulp Fiction, Ten Yards is just a copy of a copy.
Ten Yards' collection of sight gags and silliness never gels into anything more than a desperate attempt to wring laughs out of a tapped-out premise.
One of the most laughless experiences I've had at a theatre so far this year.
The Whole Ten Yards is not as desperate, unfunny, and nonsensical as its title. It's worse.
This is one of those movies you look at quizzically: What did they think they were doing?
A mostly funny film with occasional dead spots that does best letting the caricatures say exactly what you'd thought they'd say in next week's episode.
It's possibly the laziest, lamest comedy to come along in awhile.
The upside of all this -- I'm willing to bet no one will have to go through the trouble of coming up with a sequel title with the word Eleven in it.
This is the kind of farce Jack Lemmon and Tony Curtis churned out when they teamed up for The Great Race and Peter Falk and Alan Arkin gave us in The In-Laws.
A second-rate sitcom with gunplay.
A time waster.
The story makes absolutely no sense.
If [The Whole Nine Yards] should not have worked, then the sequel definitely shouldn't work, either. But, once again, it kind of does.
There's nothing in this sequel that needs to be experienced in the theater, unless you have a particular desire to see Matthew Perry smash his face into doors, cupboards and a floor or two.
As if we need further proof that Perry is not cut out for movie stardom -- either Almost Heroes or Three to Tango would suffice -- The Whole Ten Yards confirms it.
There are movies that could benefit from Three Stooges sound effects. This is one.
Slap-happy and slapdash, Ten Yards lacks the clever twists and turns that made the original such fun.

The three stars have seen better days, but I'd like to think they could still do something classier and more dignified than this. Like gay porn.
...asking the viewer to accept Tara Reid as a scientist is pure insanity, requiring a staggering leap of faith that I can't even begin to contemplate.
Worse than you can imagine... see 1997's The Relic instead.
On the short list of Worst Movies Ever Made.
They say that even ugly babies have faces their mothers love, but this is truly a film that not even hardcore genre fans could appreciate.
Perhaps hoping to be a sort of hybrid Matrix meets Indiana Jones meets Alien, Unfortunately, Alone in the Dark is just a bad movie.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: There's a point in the movie where it's best to stop trying to make sense out of this unintelligible story... right after the opening credits.

Thanks for the surgical enhancement, Tara Reid. As I always say, if saline made you a great actor then Sean Penn would have gills.
[A]n instant classic of cheeseball cinema, an orgy of overblown dialogue and hammy overacting, 90-some-odd minutes of cheap-looking, jaw-dropping incoherence...
(Christian) Slater and (Tara) Reid share quite possibly the most awkward love scene ever recorded on film.
There is a reason to fear being alone in the dark: it's this movie.
No subtext, no moral, no cultural observation, no substance; if it had calories, they would be empty

Alone in the Dark presents splatter fans with garden-variety gore, and gives action-horror fans loud, unscary special effects rather than genuine suspense or bang.
I didn't see director Uwe Boll's zombie dud House of the Dead, but on the evidence of Alone in the Dark, he belongs in the pantheon of hopelessly inept directors.
Quite possibly one of the worst movies of the decade.
The film is filled with hilariously bad performances, expository dialogue and production values that suggest it could have been a low-budget film-school project.
It's tempting to call Alone in the Dark one of those movies so bad that it's almost good. But that might send the wrong signal to Hollywood.
So poorly built, so horribly acted and so sloppily stitched together that it's not even at the straight- to-DVD level.
Frighteningly bad cinema is the only thing scary about Alone in the Dark, which gives video-game movies an even worse name, if that's possible.
As an audience-participation midnight movie, Alone in the Dark has potential.
Some concepts are meant to stay in the gaming console.
Alone in the Dark is amateurish at best and asinine at worst.
Alone in the Dark is no better than whatever you might pick up while wearing a blindfold at Blockbuster, even if you happen to reach into a trash can.
It doesn't even qualify as 'so bad it's good,' although by that standard it does have its moments.
Ultra-violent, hyper-mindless and bruisingly loud, Alone in the Dark makes its video game predecessors look like Masterpiece Theater.
Too stupid to watch, too loud to nap through, Alone in the Dark shows just how tenuous Plan Nine From Outer Space's hold on that 'worst movie ever' title really is.
Never trust a movie that opens with a written introduction scrolling by that's longer than the collected works of Tom Clancy.
A laugh-out-loud turkey.
The acting is awful and amateurish.
If you are alone in the dark with Alone in the Dark, be sure to bring chewing gum -- it will provide entertainment.
A film so mind-blowingly horrible that it teeters on the edge of cinematic immortality.
Dreadful.
Alone in the Dark is so awful, anyone who spends 10 bucks seeing it ought to get 11 bucks change and a written apology from the director and cast.
The film looks like it was made for $1.05 with its murky cinematography, sloppy special effects, and cheap sets.

Once the poorly staged mayhem erupts, there's no disguising the fact that it's all been a pointless buildup to 40 minutes of running, shooting and screaming, and you've wasted whatever time and attention you devoted to following any of its minutiae.
Veers tantalizingly close to being one of those movies that is so bad it's good, but in the end, it's so bad it's just ... bad.
Unconvincing leads, nonsensical plot, dumb staging -- this movie has it all.
Director Uwe Boll (House of the Dead) has made a cottage industry out of this kind of junk. Maybe it's time for him to close up shop.
Trying to rehash this plot is like trying to describe a Jackson Pollock painting while drunk
Alone in the Dark doesn't even deserve the indignity of going straight-to-video
Quite possibly the worst of the year. Definiately the worst of the month.

horrific and horrible
One of the worst movies ever made.

Somewhere, Ed Wood is resting pretty comfortably right now.

When the giant, intelligent bees of the future sift through the ashes of our civilization, they will find Alone in the Dark, and they will understand. It's so bad it's postmodern.
The garish editing and stilted, exposition-only dialogue induce the frisson of an America's Most Wanted re-enactment that pays unexpected, sidesplitting returns.
Wow. What an aptly named movie.
Attains a level of awe-inspiring Velveeta dunderheadedness.

[Uwe Boll] makes things on the cheap...so people keep giving him money, even though he doesn't seem to know how to point a camera at his actors, let alone operate it.

[T]he filmmakers have no more ability to tell a story than to create three-dimensional characters. They don't so much end the film as hit the reset button.
A violent and incomprehensible piece of gibberish.
Utterly lost by its end, you can just sit back and let yourself be hijacked by the movie's outrageous dialogue, hyperventilating performances and all-around commitment to overkill.
This must be stopped.
Has far more than three strikes against it.
... 96 minutes of pure torture ...
I've heard of the suspension of disbelief, but Tara Reid as an archeologist?
In this chintzy video-game blow-up, Christian Slater battles zombies and transmogrified beasties, revealing the horror of a once-promising career turned miserable.
There's plenty to snicker at.
It's just the most inept filmmaking you can catch in theatres right now, or probably all year long.
The most entertainment comes from watching Slater and Dorff and trying to figure out who's got the biggest forehead.
For as busy as this movie is, you'd think it would have more going on. Instead, it's just a big, chewy wad of badness.
You start hoping that Ashton Kutcher is going to come out and tell them they're punk'd, because you just can't believe this is for real. You feel sorry for these actors...
Para descrever este filme, vou usar um eufemismo: lixo.
Remember to get your bets in early as the Razzie winner for 2005.
Another substandard sequel.
Has just about everything a snarky bad movie lover could want--that is, except a guy and two robots sitting in the bottom right hand corner.

If you watch this movie, you are an idiot
...shockingly unfunny...
Truly this is one of the most off-putting, unpleasant and earth-shatteringly unfunny "comedies" I've ever seen.
There's bad, there's unwatchable, and then there's National Lampoon.
How Uwe Boll manages to scrape together enough investment money to give wing to this type of overblown, amateurish gibberish is truly a mystery of the cosmos...
I had the decency to stay in the theatre for the duration -- the filmmakers could have at least done the same and finished the darned movie.
Embarrassingly slipshod comedy tripe.
Mostly derivative junk, but its few novel touches are worth noting.
De Bont simply reprises the first film.
Who cares?
The most idiotic, unfunny script imaginable.
Boll's vague X-Files rip-off isn't scary or exciting, but inadvertently he's made a movie funnier than a lot of the purported comedies Hollywood cranks out.
Tenta ser uma mistura de Se7en e Ringu, mas revela-se apenas uma piada de mau gosto.
Astonishing that they could do worse than Part 1. Seriously.
Embarrassing from stem to stern
I looked at the ceiling, not casting my eyes heavenward for assistance but trying to find something more interesting to look at than what was on the screen. The ceiling won.
King's Ransom must have been funny for somebody, but I think the rest of us will be underwhelmed.
Populated solely with hateful characters...strictly for connoisseurs of crass.
Watching Anderson try to be funny is like getting a tooth pulled, or sitting through a Tim Burton DVD audio commentary.
If Hell does exist, I'm sure the only movie theatre in town will be playing nothing but Anthony Anderson movies.
Less amusing than being bound, gagged, and tortured.
A film that was so by-the-numbers that they filmed FIVE (count 'em) five different endings.
You'll feel like the one who's being held hostage.
Unobtrusive and virtually painless as an occasionally witty laugher, but lacks the courage of its convictions to follow through with its less commercial ambitions.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: The film's tag line - 'Big Man. Big Plan. Big Mistake.' sums up the decision to make the movie... big mistake.
Byrd haphazardly assembles a bunch of overly exaggerated caricatures and parades them around in a dissolving farce that has all the wayward charm of a botched lobotomy
The desperately unfunny kidnapping farce King's Ransom is the cinematic equivalent of trampled chewing gum on a subway platform.
If Anderson can land the role of a corporate shark who's surrounded by hot babes, it's conceivable we could soon see Jennifer Lopez as the lead in 'Memoirs of a Geisha'...
One of those barbarically unfunny romps that would be over in less than 10 minutes if just one character had an IQ higher than a cherry Pop-Tart.

Devoid of anything resembling wit or even guiltily amusing tasteless gags, the film lurches from one haplessly staged sequence to another, with the performers vainly struggling to infuse humor into the proceedings.
The Chronicle's Little Man was fighting an internal struggle to abandon his chair altogether, but was ultimately swayed to continue his nap, mostly by a few of the comics in supporting roles.

None of this is remotely funny, despite screenwriter Wayne Conley's resorting to virtually every known stereotype about African-Americans and more crass references to menstruation and prison sex than have ever appeared in a movie rated PG-13.
After a while, all these odious, yammering people start to sound a lot like Charlie Brown's teacher. And they somehow all end up together at a time and a place you do not want to be.
Merely a collection of antics clothespinned to a plot.

Somewhere in a pitch meeting someone must have piped up: 'I know. We'll have a guy named 'King' and he gets kidnapped, see? So there's a 'ransom'! King's Ransom, get it? After that, I've got nothing.'
Doesn't pay off.
If you shelve out even $1 for this movie, you'll feel as though you've paid a "King's Ransom."
With the humor in this lazy farce about as subtle as a shotgun blast to the face, it's possible to see the whole movie as an accident, the cumulative result of haphazard negligence.
The scenarios are halfway convincing and at times even passably clever; they are never, however, especially funny.
Achieves a rare form of badness.
Little in this film suggests 'director' Jeff Byrd and writer Wayne Conley possess any facility -- or familiarity -- with irony or any other comedic device.
Spurn King's Ransom as you would spurn a rabid weasel.
King's Ransom is a wit-deficient barrage of obnoxious characters and second-hand punchlines.
[A] crass, trashy and none-too-funny comedy.
Marital bickering, a mistaken-identity sex romp and booty shots galore follow, but few laughs.
The climactic assassination attempt... is so ridiculous there's only one real danger: that the president (and the audience) will laugh to death.
Screenwriter' Wayne Conley's idea of side-splitting dialogue is to have characters repeatedly tell King to "kiss their black ass." Or announce that they just "pooted."
Needless to say, as a cringe-worthy and excruciatingly awful comedy, you shouldn't pay a dime of King's Ransom.
All these plots converge in a decidedly unfunny cacophony.
Mean-spirited, unpleasant comedy about characters who are both nasty and stupid and who deserve every bad thing that happens to them. In fact, they deserve more.
Byrd's romp through the most contemptible stereotypes of women, gays, and ethnic minorities makes his film unfit for just about anyone, never mind royalty.
A mirthless comedy about venal people doing stupid things.
This pudgy, obvious DeNiro is definitely not the one I grew up admiring.
One of the most astonishingly idiotic pieces of entertainment I've ever had the displeasure of sitting through.
Basically an improv scene sprawling to feature length.
(Anthony) Anderson is funny, usually. Just not here.
Absolutely awful.
I couldn't pay anyone to see this movie. Literally.
Game Over
As long as director Uwe Boll is given money to make films, we are guaranteed at least one unintentionally uproarious gut-buster a year.
Ladies and gentlemen, I present to you Exhibit A in the evidence that no more video games, under any conditions, should be made into movies.
This is pretty close to one of the worse movies that I've ever seen and having to recap it is making my brain bleed..
Just like nearly all of Judd's past entries in the genre, this film isn't great, it's just average.

Eu devia ter suspeitado de algo quando meu aparelho de DVD pareceu se recusar a rodar este filme. E posso jurar que ele pediu um Cepacol depois que a tortura chegou ao fim.

Uwe Boll's best videogame adaptation yet. Wait... what does that even mean?
Head-slapping, what-the-f*ck-is-this-for-real? trippiness.
