Cinema this toxic can either kill you with laughter or simply turn your brain into a pool of sex-obsessed pudding.
King's Ransom lumbers forth clumsily, choreographing its slapstick pratfalls with all the class and taste of a Courtney Love relapse.
It's one of those movies that is so bad that if you watch it in the right frame of mind, you can actually enjoy it. You just have to revel in its badness.
Filled with artificial sweetener, and ultimately not satisfying enough.
A ludicrous and laughable sequel that desecrates the name of a fantastic original.
While most sequels have nowhere to go, this sequel has nowhere it wants to go, and while most movie failures are unoriginal, this mess is simply uninspired.
It would be easier to forgive some of the film's excesses, however, if it were actually funny.
Robert de Niro - once great actor whose name on a poster now tells anyone interested in good film to run to the hills
Horror remakes like this one paint all the others with a huge and objectionable brush, because this flick absolutely stinks of half-hearted effort and assembly-line cynicism.
Who knows? Maybe if we ignore these pointless remakes enough, pretty soon they'll all go away.
The second absolutely atrocious remake in 2005 of a John Carpenter movie...And where's Tom Atkins when you need him?
Wainwright's Fog proves successful only at blowing.
A textbook example of how not to make a horror film.
It's rather refreshing to encounter an almost quaintly retro thriller that depends more on tension and suggestion than on gross-out effects.
a plot that has been reworked into something resembling crudely made hash
A movie where everyone's last breath ends in a scream. Where is Adrienne Barbeau when we need her?
The Fog is a bore, laden with unspectacular special effects and dreadful acting from television-trained youth who don't have the experience to truly deliver the goods.
Maggie Grace can be snobby-scared, or snobby-haughty, or even snobby-injured, but she can't seem to leave that snobbyness behind, no matter what is chasing her.
Irredeemably irresponsible.
Hollywood is a remake junky and we're its enablers. How long before the studio system has a fatal overdose? The Fog could do it. Moviedom, you need help.
Like watching a cut-rate Roger Corman rip-off of a big Hollywood film, only the tables are ironically turned. The big budget studio version seems pale in comparison.
proof that maybe even moviegoers should sue
Anthony Anderson shows he can star in a movie without a kangaroo in this kidnapping plan gone crazy.
...enduring The Fog is like trying to swim effortlessly through a giant bowl of dripping and sticky pea soup-it's messy and just as pointless.
The Union of Fog Machine Operators can be proud of its contributions to this yawner.
Carl Sandburg once wrote that the fog comes on little cat feet. Director Rupert Wainwright's 'The Fog,' however, clomps around like an elephant in cement boots.
It's atmospheric, but only in the literal sense.
This Fog lacks the one thing the original had -- originality -- but it qualifies as more than a mist opportunity.
It's typical of pic's adherence to rigid genre conventions that the very first victims are brazen hotties who are shown drinking, dancing and wearing revealing attire prior to their deaths.
A soggy ghost story wrapped in an aggressively swirling wall of mist.
It is all utterly formulaic and predictable, and there's not even a rooting interest in trying to figure out who might live and who might die.
Add one more to the list of unnecessary horror remakes.

The fog also does something genuinely eerie: It causes everyone in the cast to deliver dreadful performances and display inappropriate reactions when their friends are drowned, burned, stabbed or thrown into glass display cases.
I was held in suspense throughout The Fog, aching to learn the answer to its central riddle: Why would any one remake such a crummy movie?
Lock your doors. Bolt your windows. And for heaven's sake, stay away from the multiplex.
Yes, there's "something in 'The Fog,'" all right. Another weekend of low box office proceeds and more dismal reviews for yet another unnecessary, poorly made remake.
It attempts to apply too much logic to the events going on that it distracts the viewer from pleasure and replaces it with boredom.
"We gotta go!" Poor Nick (Tom Welling) says this a few too many times in The Fog.
We're meant to be unsettled by digital spectres, reckless Mack trucks, and rotting old pirates who look every bit as terrifying as the guy on the Fisherman's Friend cold-lozenge box.
Simply, irredeemably, insufferably boring -- the one thing a horror picture just can't survive.
You may jump and wince a couple of times, but only because the soundtrack features a few loud bangs that are cranked up beyond pain threshold.
A film riddled with missed opportunities for good clean scares.
Even foggier than the disappointing original.
Although it's rehash, it's not that bad...wait to rent it.
Mold-covered clichs are the most frightening things in The Fog.
The foggy bottom boys are back and kicking up quite a fuss in The Fog, a fright-filled remake of John Carpenter's 1980 horror thriller.
It seems to set a record for the quantity of shock moments that involve either a pane of glass breaking or something catching fire.
Making concessions at every turn to the youth-horror market, the film slashes the ages of its protagonists by some 15 years, and its IQ follows suit.
Mildly scary here and there.
That John Carpenter, credited here as a producer, had a hand in diminishing his own legacy would be tragic if any of this mattered.
Like most remakes, The Fog is pretty unnecessary.
The acting is stilted and the direction clunky - not that the original was any masterpiece.
A pale remake of a 25-year-old horror film that wasn't all that memorable to begin with.

[It] pales in comparison to Carpenter's original fogbanks, some of which were created by optical effects nearly as ancient as filmmaking itself but still vastly more believable than anything seen in this absolutely dreadful and just plain dull remake.
There's no good reason for another rendition of John Carpenter's 1980 film about the ghosts of drowned lepers seeking revenge on the inhabitants of a seaside California town.
Either way, give it a week or two and it's a sure bet The Fog will already have disappeared from theaters along with the morning dew.
better than expected, but, considering the reputation of its author, this isn't much of an achievement
Don't bother.
A better title for this film would have been Dazed and Confused. That's certainly how I felt afterwards.
The In Crowd isn't a movie--it's a J. Crew catalogue. Junk mail, junk movie.
It's as painful to watch as Rodman's star-posturing interviews.
If you want to be frightened, don't bother with this remake.
It's pretty campy-silly, but it's surprisingly watchable for some reason, maybe because of the name-brand actors sleazing it in this Skinemax would-be classic.
With such diminished expectations, one must wonder if it is a good thing that the film is merely bad instead of a cinematic atrocity.
Actors have bills to pay too, and who knows, maybe Transylvania is nice in the summer.

I'm not sure what Boll sees when he looks through the director's lens while filming each of his pictures, but I'm certain it's something different than what the rest of us see. BloodRayne poses no threat to his reputation.
Whatever else you may think of Boll's directorial 'skills,' you can't fault him for inconsistency -- his movies are always atrocious, and Bloodrayne is no exception.
It's bad, but not painfully bad like Boll's previous two...BloodRayne is just an ordinary, formulaic sword-and-sorcery B movie with one hot sex scene.
Flip to any random sequence in BloodRayne and you'll see a film professor's most vibrant nightmare.
BloodRayne makes me wish that Mystery-Science Theater 3000 was still on the air. This would be perfect for them.
... easily the R-rated sex and gore movie every 14-year old teen secretly sneaks up to watch after his parents go to bed.
Though indisputably the best of Uwe Boll's first three video-game-into-film adaptations, this gory, ludicrous horror-action picture isn't good by any standard.
Less pleasurable than the throbbing bladder pain begat by too much movie theater soda, BloodRayne ably continues Uwe Boll's indisputable reign as the worst filmmaker on the planet.
BloodRayne is a visual joke, with Boll limply organizing a period horror/action film with all the confidence and subtlety of Baby Huey, and with about the same level of literacy.
There's nothing certain in life except death, taxes and ... that movies based on video games are going to stink. Cue BloodRayne.
BloodRayne fails as mindless entertainment and as eye candy, violating the basic laws of both vampire films and cheesy videogame adaptations: It can't even suck right.
What was the point of any of it? Only 'Dr. Boll' seems to know. On second thought, based on the evidence in front of the camera, maybe he doesn't.
Michael Madsen? Michelle Rodriguez? 'I'll take "Actors Who Should Never Appear in Period Pieces" for $500, Alex.'
An astronomically awful movie; the only question is whether it's worse than Uwe Boll's last atrocity 'Alone in the Dark,' and you might say it wins by Ben Kingsley's nose.
...[an] undercooked formulaic fright fable...why would anyone let him (Boll) get three feet within the range of an operating movie camera?
There isn't much more of a story. In fact, there isn't any story. Luckily, Loken is there to provide something to stare at, vacantly.
Madsen sounds like Mike Myer's "SNL" character "Lothar of the Hill people".
It never occurs to you to think of the film as anything other than a silly swords-and-castles tale, and a particularly ineffective one at that.

Halfway through, the guys put Rayne through a training sequence, even though we've just seen her kick butt for 45 minutes, then there's a long, talky stretch that is woefully short of impaling - perhaps suggesting that the movie's financing was dwindling.
A bad-beyond-belief gorefest that provides no chills, scant excitement and a bumper crop of unintentional laughs. ...sure to reappear in many 'worst of the year' recaps.
The film might be the first of its kind: something to bring Maxim subscribers, video gamers, and loyal Logo viewers together.

Pic lurches from incident to incident at a graceless plodding place, offering little in the way of genuine excitement -- the swordfights often are confusingly cut and choreographed -- and only minimal amounts of guilty-pleasure titillation.

How fitting that director Uwe Boll (House of the Dead) would choose a vampire flick as his latest project - the man has a career that, despite the horror he continually inflicts on innocent moviegoers, simply will not die.
Uwe Boll is such a bad director that it must be intentional.
Most of the budget seems to have been spent on the cast, with apparently little left over for sets or costumes.
After Rayne breaks out of the circus, it's a simple story, really, about a mixed-up girl who wants to slay her father.
If I thought for a minute this Roquefort-riddled camp-fest was as intentionally ridiculous, stilted, witless and over-the-top as it actually is, I'd congratulate Boll.
It's time to start paying attention to the oeuvre of German director Uwe Boll. At this rate, he'll become the Ed Wood of this new movie century.
It's essentially a feature length version of what could have been told in a five-minute flashback sequence during a real BloodRayne movie.
It'd be a stretch to call the movie good, but at least it's fun-bad.

BloodRayne is a movie of unconnected plot dots. In the hands of director Uwe "German Tax Dodge" Boll, a simple sword and sorcery story with vampiric overtones turns into genre-jumping attempts to find an audience.
Who is Uwe Boll and why does he hate moviegoers so? The German hack, the one-man Blitzkrieg of Bad, is the worst filmmaker in the movies today.
When on-line petitions beg directors to stop making films, is that the beginning of the end?
[Uwe Boll] is fast becoming known as one of the worst directors on the planet.
It's as if Boll brought together the best team of talent he could possibly secure on short notice and then told them all to suck. And they do!
The supporting cast is mind-melting: Michael Madsen is as out of place in this Medieval milieu as Meat Loaf in a hoop skirt, and Meat Loaf is just out of place.
Pale WB-style hunks and hotties and a 'funny' black guy whose sole purpose is to say words like 'dawg' confront a CGI mist that looks like it could be erased with a couple of mouse clicks.
The clunking exposition, narrative incoherence and abysmal dialogue might find favour with aficionados of bad films, but even they won't forgive the sheer nasty mindedness of this lurid mess.
Masquerading as a commentary on the greedy '80s, this is clearly the sort of moronic comedy beloved of the Weekend at Bernie's team of Kotcheff and writer Robert Klane.

Al (Prinze) and Imogen (Stiles) are 19-year-olds tackling New York college life. The course of their relationship is charted in numbing detail and interspersed with the antics of their quirky friends.
Travolta, it seems, had wanted to star in a film of Battlefield Earth since first reading the novel in 1982. Only the all-seeing L Ron knows why.
The humour is sufficiently scattershot to hit the mark once or twice, but basically a no-brains comedy.
All in all, not as bad as you'd suspect and certainly serviceable for all who love the bloody, low-budget vamping gone wild.
A dull, stupid, boring picture, inferior in every way to the John Carpenter film it remakes, but it's bad for the same reason a lot of effects-driven movies are bad.
A limp, smirky lark.
Played straight, this could make some quite serious points about the predicament of the unemployed (Pryor as prostitute), but the film finds it easier to opt for cheap laughs.
So far, so hackneyed.
There's little noteworthy.
Dafoe's take on Dennis Hopper's Hopper impersonation is plain pointless; Bullock too is wasted in a ditzy half-role; and Patric is unsmiling and resolutely uncharismatic.
Place it next to The Omega Code and The Omega Code shines.

Sarah Thorpe's screenplay is a compendium of by-the-book clich√©s; Kaufman's direction leaves the material stranded in a limbo between po-faced and trashy; Judd's approximation of drunkenness is worrying to behold.
There follows a fusillade of farts, dud sight gags and inconsequential butt jokes.
Like a sex education film made by semi-liberated nuns, the movie keeps its sticky truths hidden beneath a veneer of leering cleanliness.
Enough to make you gag.
Another remake bites the dust.
Even showing lots of Bo Derek's beautiful nude body isn't enough to save Bolero from terminal boredom.
A mediocre remake of a 1980s horror movie of the same name which wasn't that good to begin with.
...the latest in a long line of needless horror remakes..

The actors do their best, under the circumstances. Welling makes an engaging lead and Grace employs her trademarked wounded, fragile look (that serves her so well in Lost) to good effect and wanders around in her underwear a lot.
If you are a fan of the original film, this remake might interest you. It's not badly made. But why was it made at all?
With dialogue as dorky as the words new screenwriter Cooper Lane stuffed in their mouths, none of the hapless cast members could have sounded convincing.
This is one of those rare films that truly manages to get by on unintentional laughs, but otherwise dreadful.
Don't be afraid.
The script is so bland it barely musters a whole ten laughs.
Watching Battlefield Earth is to a movie-watching experience what having a yeast infection is to having sex.
So how does a filmmaker bounce back from an almost universally reviled action-horror mistake? Well, if your name is Uwe Boll, you don't.
A lousy remake of a not-so-good John Carpenter film.
This is a movie that begs you not to watch it.
Mindless, stylish fun.
Rollerball looks like a checklist shaped by a 15-year-old mallrat: thrashing metal track, skateboards, motorbikes, cracked heads and Rebecca Romijn-Stamos with her top off.
The use of child jeopardy as a cheap suspense mechanism is somewhat dubious, but one's unease is slightly mollified by the fact that much of this is far too silly to take seriously.
Erotic, surely, only for the very easily pleased.
Inane and shopworn material with a truly cheesy final twist, this is made excruciating by direction that takes it all deadly seriously.
Sadly, Sheen doesn't even look profound. Like a zombie who's spent too much time in the gym, he blunders heavily from one stunt to the next, his pursed lips conveying nothing more than pique.

Sometimes, when you've just wasted a tenner and a perfectly good evening watching another dumb, gratuitously gun-filled, hackneyed, nonsensical action picture, don't you wish you were as thick, lazy and easily pleased as Hollywood wants you to be?

Any chance for suspense is thwarted by gratuitous violence, heavy-metal-propelled action sequences and laughably flat dialogue between characters who are barely more developed than in the Atari version.
Yet another anaemic horror retread starring a cast of good-looking TV totty.
The preponderance of nudging innuendo was enough to earn the film a '12' certificate, thus excluding the audience of younger children who might otherwise have enjoyed the movie.
The script is formula and so is the direction, which leaves the acting.
All could be forgiven if it weren't for the soulless overall slickness.
An embarrassingly nonsensical misfire.
Twisted is so bad I'm embarrassed to have seen it and therefore am a bit ashamed to write even an unkind review.
Only as bad as ordinary bad films and not as bad as getting your eyelid caught on a nail.
A comedy only Dr. Kevorkian could have loved.
[Relies] on cheap shocks instead of honestly exploring how the parents of a dead child might feel about raising his clone.
Yes, it's allegedly based on books by Jason Lethcoe, but it bears little or no resemblance to them.
Featuring a bizarrely dated soundtrack fueled by new music from Smash Mouth, Zoom was designed as a film of training montages. I stopped counting after a half-dozen.
If you can overlook the snot and fart material that litters the screenplay, the grotesque product placement, along with the rancid Smash Mouth soundtrack, Zoom actually has a faint ability to please.

The whole thing is a PG-rated greatest hits collection, elements of so many other pictures popping up throughout one could almost make a game of trying to spot and catalogue them all before things run their well-known course.
It's a contender for Worst Kid Movie of 2006.
An irritating 83-minute music montage posing as a feature film, Zoom is the worst family release so far this year.
In terms of age level, Zoom stands somewhere between Baby Geniuses and The Adventures of Pluto Nash, but it's just as bad as both of them.

Allen falls somewhere in between phoning this performance in and giving it a half-hearted try. Courteney Cox approaches her role (his love interest in a lab coat) like she'd very much like to be back on Friends.
If Tim Allen really was a superhero, his name would be Blandman. His power: turn even the most innocuous kiddie movie into something nearly unwatchable.
It has plenty of energy and visual effects but not a single original idea in its spandex-clad head.
A crashing, thudding dullness infects every moment of Zoom.
The director of Zoom is Peter Hewitt, who also directed Garfield. Nothing more to say about that.
One of the most dismal excuses for family entertainment ever perpetrated by a major studio.
The under-achieving Zoom resembles nothing so much as as a subpar episode of a failed Disney Channel teleseries.

Frankly, this would have been a perfect candidate for the straight-to-DVD shelf. But the young stars are appealing, and at this point in his career, Allen could carry a family film with one hand tied behind his back.
Cox falls down three times, Allen belches and Chase gets covered with buckets of green snot. Scenes keep ending on non-jokes like this exchange: 'No way!' 'Way!'
Shabbily filmed and resolutely unfunny.
When the lights come up after a mercifully short 88 minutes, you'll want to bolt for the exit. Faster than a speeding bullet.
Your ability to tolerate this movie depends on how much music from the band Smashmouth you can stand.
Fails to ever really find its focus as a story
Too infantile for tweens and too stagnant for tots, Zoom bleeds boredom from every frame.
Seeing the once-great Chevy Chase reduced to this bug-eyed buffoonery is sad, like watching an old man crap his pants at the grocery store.
Family-friendly premise notwithstanding, this seemingly innocuous fare scarcely hides the contempt most studio executives must harbor for their audiences.
There's not a single thing to like in this dump of a movie. But I'm sure your children will enjoy the Kids Meal.
Nobody involved with Zoom seems to get the appeal of comic books or kid superheroes. It doesn't help that the film was clearly produced on the cheap.

Just picture, if you will, Chevy Chase being covered by green slime. From someone's nose. If that's sets you guffawing, you won't want to miss "Zoom," an alleged family movie that is nothing of the sort.
Just exactly how desperate are you to get the kids out of the house and into the theater?
Dulled down into a mayo-and-bologna on white by a succession of dependably bland post-'Home Improvement' trifles, the light is gone from the eyes of Tim Allen.
Zoom is a bad movie. It's badly written, badly directed, badly acted, badly edited, badly scored and beyond badly overdubbed.
Zoom is a movie that you've probably seen several times already.
Zoom is another one of those endearingly cheap, twice-annual Tim Allen movies that seem to be forever playing on airplanes. (Next up is Santa Clause 3.)
Lackadaisically executed on every level.
derivative kiddie adventure falls flat on its face.
A cheap, ugly, forgettable footnote to the seemingly endless superhero boom.
It's OK entertainment for preteens, while Cox adds some slapstick and love interest as a klutzy psychiatrist.
In all truthfulness, Zoom was better than I thought it would be...and by that, I mean that it didn't completely suck.
Certainly doesn't bode well for either Duff Sister if this is the best script coming their way.
In a feat of dullness quite powerful in its own way, this lifeless family comedy sucks the joy from every joke it touches; X-Men's Rogue would be envious.
Playi[s] like a cross between Galaxy Quest and Sky High but without the wit and cleverness of either film...

Stink jokes, snot jokes, Smash Mouth songs, dependably dull Tim Allen, some truly obnoxious product placement and 'We're more than a team, we're a family' bromides leach the potential pleasure from this overfamiliar story...
Save your allowance, kids -- a mall trip would be way more fun than this ditzy Duff fluff.

The film opens with the Duffs huffing and puffing their way through a remake of Madonna's 'Material Girl,' an ode to gold digging that Madonna sang with a touch of wry humor; the Duffs perform it as if it was 'The Battle Hymn of the Republic.'
Paris and Nicky Hilton exhibit more character nuance. And they're vaguely more entertaining to watch.
Nonsensical from the get-go, the girls' fish-out-of-water routine grows interminable.
Madonna's anthem was only good-naturedly arrogant, but the SoCal twins, like the film's script, are arrogant, ghastly immature and offensive to any audience that isn't all of the above.
There is no edge to the movie at all, and that blandness will render it forgettable to anyone over the age of 12 or so, but for all that, it is pleasant enough, and occasionally even fun.
Light but listless.
You may find yourself longing for the intricate plotting and ensemble acting skills of the Olsen twins movies.
A superficial tween comedy that mocks celebutantes like the Olsen twins while simultaneously pushing stars Hilary and Haylie Duff as their replacements.
Is Anjelica Huston in need of work? Is that why she's in this piece of crap?
As a film that sets out to poke fun at the LA, St Tropez tan, famous for being famous, stupid small dogs lifestyle, its far too candy-coated and lacks bite, while the comic timing is off.
When it comes to action, comedy, and drama, three words apply: lamer, lamer, lamest.

The kids are cute, Allen is affable and charming, and Chevy Chase shows flashes of his old brilliance, but mostly it's a little kid movie with bad CGI effects and nary a moment of real jeopardy or emotion.
At the very least, Material answers the question everyone wants to know: yes, Haylie is the better actress.
Stays true to its name, all right, but there's no reason the film also had to be an embarrassingly unfunny and aimless chore to sit through.
This is indeed one dumb film.
With the exception of Anjelica Huston's regal supporting turn, 'Material Girls' is an immaterial movie.
You might remember it from May when it starred Lindsay Lohan and was called Just My Luck.

There's a happily ever after ending complete with cute new boyfriends. But on the way there, the movie has a surprising number of inapprpriate and ugly choices considering the target audience and the PG rating.
finally drives a Duff vehicle into the land of beguilingly awful.
First the good news: This film isn't nearly as awful as some would have you believe. Now the bad: It still sucks.
Maybe Immaterial Girls would have been a more appropriate title.
The scariest part of Material Girls comes when you're sitting in the dark theater and start considering the possibility that young women might find these characters sympathetic.
The movie, which was not screened for critics, makes a joke of everyone who isn't wealthy, white and pencil thin.
It's sort of reassuring that although Madge has seemingly given up starring in bad movies, her company is still financing terrible scripts.
Even by the low standards of the genre it represents, this female teen comedy represents a new nadir.
It succeeds on its own terms. These days, even pre teens live in a material world.
The fact is, neither Hilary nor Haylie have any flair for subtle comedy.
An incompetent spin on the poor-little-rich-girl story, the film involves a lot of wardrobe changes and product placements, and a smidgen of intrigue and some chaste romance.
Infantile, unfocused and dreadfully inept, Zoom is badly conceived...a totally faceless fable that strains for enlightenment but merely ends up as disastrous diversion
I liked it better with Brittany Murphy.
Want to see child superheroes? See Sky High, Spy Kids or The Incredibles. And Tim Allen is better and more curmudgeonly in the Santa Clause films
It's not Clueless, just clueless.
I barely buy them as sisters, let alone as whoever these characters are supposed to be.
Despite whatever connotations its title might suggest, Zoom is a movie marked by pure laziness, made by folks who either don't know or don't care what they're doing.
As if one Duff wasn't enough for us.
Woe is the Marchetta sisters!
This comedy drags its feet, while the sappy sweetness will make you wince.
Ever the foolish optimist, I actually expected to enjoy Zoom.
Martha Coolidge's direction treats the whole adventure with more respect than it deserves, which also makes one wish that she'd been able to work with the Duffs on something much more worthwhile.
[It] isn't some light send-up of materialism. It's a light endorsement of it.
Just as streetball is a pale version of college or NBA basketball, so too is Crossover a pathetic imitation of an emotionally engaging, professionally made movie.
The chances of it actually 'crossing over' are nil.
A couple of dramatic plot points come and go with the speed of a buzzer-beating shot. And like the style of play the film glorifies, it's all flash and no fundamentals.
Crossover skimps on court-level pyrotechnics (we get a game in the beginning and, of course, a big game at the end, and that's about it) in favor of dry urban melodrama.
Wayne Brady, even at his most intimidating, is about as threatening as a basket full of kittens.
There will never be a tamer, lamer movie made about streetball.
The streetball scenes offer some nifty trick plays, but the rest of Crossover features poorly dressed sets, cheap-looking costumes and locations, and silly histrionics.
Compared to those prodigious in-your-face fakes, alley oops and slam dunks, the movie's trite, trash-talking dialogue and drippy do-the-right-thing message fall as flat as an airball.
Crossover comes with more swooshing/zapping/whamming sound effects than a year's worth of The O'Reilly Factor.
The movie just flails away at a lot of plot points that are either second-hand playground hustles straight out of White Man Can't Jump -- or second-rate.
You could watch Crossover, or you could check out the Salvation Army gift shop to see what inspirational bumper stickers they're peddling.
The underground version of basketball known as streetball comes above ground in Crossover, but the fascinating freeform game gets screened out by a ludicrous soap opera with poor dramatic moves.

This sanitized version of inner-city life deserves points for its game attempt to create an uplifting tale, but outside some flashy basketball sequences, it rarely comes to life or generates much believability.
Crossover is a movie that fouls out in the first half.

While director-screenwriter Preston A. Whitmore II's film is to be admired for its proponing the values of a higher education over the dream of a career in the NBA, its dialogue, characterizations and situations rarely transcend the level of cliche.
Melodramatically absurd and technically inept...well-intentioned but dull.
It shoots. And it shoots and shoots and shoots, but it never scores.
Crossover is not just awful, it's gloriously, stupendously, magnificently awful. And best of all, it has Wayne Brady as the bad guy.
A cheap-looking quickie feature...the wasted talent on display somehow makes it all more painful.
Crossover might have its heart in the right place, but its brain is somewhere else all together.
Pure Amateursville.
The entire film is just so over-the-top, feeling more like an After School Special than a serious inner-city drama.
If you're old enough to see how shamelessly manipulative and predictable it is, you're too old for it.
This is a neo-minstral show.
Clunky, clich-filled and embarrassingly melodramatic.
The talky script, by the movie's director Preston A. Whitmore II, is delivered with all the flair of bad community theater.
The writing is unimaginative -- Tech says 'snap' more often than that elf from the cereal commercials.

The only thing that makes the game streetball, as is explained by overexpository dialogue, is that strict rules aren't really enforced, and the players are allowed to travel. I know what you're thinking -- how is this different from the NBA?
Earnest and predictable, Crossover deserves more than the horselaughs that will probably greet it in theaters -- but not a lot more.
The would-be street hoopster characters of Crossover have plenty of flashy, original moves. Sadly, the movie itself has none.
Crossover expects moviegoers to ignore the inept script and acting and root for its characters anyway.
Cross Crossover off your list of movies to see.
Crossover could've used a little more sports action in place of some overwrought melodrama.

Crossover has too much going for it. It has a wonderful message about making smart life choices, but the story shuffles among too many subjects -- sports, romance, friendship -- to let audiences hear it clearly.

An inner-city drama promoting themes of friendship, loyalty and the value of a good education should be a welcome event, but writer-director Preston Whitmore's Crossover is so badly conceived and executed, its good intentions don't help.
I'll believe that Kevin Federline is a Renaissance man, Mel Gibson loves matzoh and George Pataki is going to be our next president before I'll believe the premise of this movie.
For a movie centered on a game without rules, Crossover is pretty formulaic.
The games and setting aren't gritty enough to let this urban sports drama crossover into something a general audience would care to see.
Bling is bad and friends are good in this story of temptation, rivalry and buck-wild cheerleaders set in the world of Detroit street basketball.
An amateurish hodgepodge of drama clichs and tired music video-style techniques, Crossover is a baldly contrived narrative.

A lot of Crossover's manifest failings could be forgiven if the on-court action was thrilling. But Space Jam had better basketball scenes. For that matter, so did Dr. J's The Fish That Saved Pittsburgh.

Crossover has one redeeming quality: a heart that's in the right place. It's a bad movie with a good message -- but does anyone really want to pay $10 for an ABC After School Special version of He Got Game?
You can't blame Crossover for being comfortable with its own clichs. It's so blatantly formulaic that it actually grows on you if you don't dismiss it in the first five minutes.

Detroit-born independent filmmaker Preston A. Whitmore II's astonishingly inept drama revolves around the high-stakes world of streetball and the efforts of two teenagers to resist its flash and cash temptations.
Just a few more tweaks and Crossover could have been something special -- a truly terrible movie to savor for the ages. But nooo, this street ball movie has to settle for middle-of-the-road badness.

What is most surprising, however, is just how bad the basketball in the movie is. The games bookending the picture are two of the worst cinematic interpretations of the sport ever to grace the silver screen.
The Annapolis of basketball movies... The movie bounces from scene to scene like some sort of round rubbery sphere.
Much as they would like it to, basketball can't save the youthful inner-city players here. Nor does the ultra-fast-paced street version of the sport save this movie from predictability and tedium.
Even I could play against these guys and maybe win.
Crossover's got game, not to mention the best of intentions. But it's too clunky by half.
An end-of-summer throwaway that resembles last year's Supercross in its naked ineptitude and willingness to cut corners at every turn.

The villain (a greedy corporate man of some sort) isn't very fleshed out, but it's hard to believe that he's any worse than the two self-serving, appearance-obsessed protagonists, with whom the film asks young girls everywhere to identify.
Despite a superb cast, Crossover dribbles slowly, with not nearly enough time on the basketball court.
The movie looks as though it was edited in a Cuisinart, more concerned with frenetic cutting than coherent storytelling.
I hated this movie. It's a piece of junk.
The beginning of Crossover looks like a mash-up of McG's Fastlane and Wayne Brady's storied appearance on Chappelle's Show.
If you've seen the full trailer for The Covenant, well, you've seen just about all this movie has to offer.
Here's a story that wanders all over the place with an ending that just about anybody could predict.
Where do WB pilots go when they die? Perhaps they're reincarnated as lousy supernatural thrillers.
it's really nothing more than really bad dialogue spoken by some of the most beautiful kids in Hollywood who can't act their way out of a paper bag
Moviegoers need to band together for a covenant -- stop buying tickets to Renny Harlin movies.
Cleverly takes the lure of illegal drugs and links it to super powers.
A guys-for-girls version of Charmed. It's sad indeed when one's making movies that wouldn't even have passed muster on a network that no longer exists.
[Harlin] still can stage a decent super-natural battle royale. But he couldn't scare a mouse. Nor does The Covenant.
The Covenant virtually resets the bar for mediocrity in horror thrillers.
... a diluted remix of Lost Boys.
Essentially, Covenant is about young, wet, 'CW' ready underwear models running around hurling 'magical' gelatin blobs at each other while they compete for screen time with their own abs.

It's all furiously supercilious idiotic fluff, and maybe I was just in a freakishly forgiving mood when I saw it but for some insane reason I found The Covenant to be gloriously kitschy B-movie entertainment.
It fails utterly as a horror picture, although it delivers plenty of PG-13-rated flesh and unintentional laughs.

A few funny lines spool out intermittently, but it's the inane-ness of Material Girls that grates. While Hollywood sisters Haylie and Hilary Duff tell each other money doesn't bring happiness, their actions speak otherwise
None of them can act worth a lick, but all of them would be perfect for an Abercrombie & Fitch catalogue.
Limitless powers, and all we get are some spiders, some Blobs, and some supernatural hair gel.

The latest from a generation of filmmakers whose influence stems primarily from WB sitcom aesthetics and PlayStation videogame storylines, The Covenant falls into theaters like a fashion magazine adapted to the screen.
Whoops! A schlocky direct-to-video thriller accidentally got released into theaters!
This sophomoric supernatural stinker couldn't put a convincing spell on a disabled frog. The Covenant has all the intriguing mysticism of a bent magic wand.
All that's truly scary about The Covenant are the words that appear before the title: 'A Renny Harlin Film.'
... one hopes, perhaps naively, that there'd be some kind of message amid the special effects and nubile bodies.
This sort of thing might work as a desperation rental -- like if you've been injected with poison and must keep watching incredibly lame movies or die ...
... Covenant is devoid of any real scares.
The Covenant is a terrible movie, a bucket of water on the teen-witch genre.
... profoundly mediocre ...
It's super lame.
... if this mild teen thriller were a cigarette, it would be a Salem light.
... as chilling as a steam shower.
The Covenant has excellent special effects (spiders and specters, oh my!), but it is strikingly lacking in suspense.
[An] eardrum-punishing, uninspired composite of X-Men and the Harry Potter series ...
nothing more than a bunch of Abercrombie and Fitch models and some special effects.
... a supernatural teen drama that wouldn't be so bad if you didn't have to pay good money to see it.
The Covenant is highly derivative, lazily shot and jaggedly edited. It's yet another example of how Renny Harlin has become the very model of a modern major hack.
This inane film is definitely a wayward canine in need of an animal-control officer.
Anyone with half a brain is not this movie's target audience.
No one has bothered to develop a coherent story or remotely likable characters to sustain the CGI effects, ear-splitting music, and hyperactive editing.
The Covenant is just a copycat.
Rejoice: it's a little like a cross between The Lost Boys and Zapped!.
This is cobbled-together teenybopper tripe about feuding male witches with nothing to offer but classic bad dialogue.
This supernatural story doesn't muster much horror, much less tap into the thriller aspect.
Here's a sort of "The Craft" with males at its center.
It's as if the WB took Harry Potter and turned it into Five Hot Underwear Models Go Back to High School and Do Magic...
WB-style homoerotic teen escapism.
The idiocy and sheer laziness of the whole concept ought to be the sort of thing director Renny Harlin (Deep Blue Sea) could make into glorious cinematic cheese...but he's hamstrung
There is not a scary scene in the whole movie.
With its barely-distinguishable teen-model cast and earnestness, it comes off like an overlong episode of a WB series that never got off the ground.
I would not encourage you to waste your money on this one.
The inspirational sports movie cliches notwithstanding, Crossover is just bad filmmaking that does not serve either its cast or its audience well.
doesn't move in any direction and instead wanders without much aim at all
The script is long on the Big Issues, but comes up short in compelling dialogue. It needed a couple more drafts.
The streetball scenes, much like the plot, have a few high points but never hit their stride.
There are dumb movies and then there is Crossover, a movie so devoid of logic it will leave you astounded.
Writer-director Preston Whitmore II's basketball film is a well-intentioned but utterly clichd slice of Detroit life.

quote: If BET made after school specials, this is what they would look like.

[A] muddled and most unmagical offering.
