Crass and joyless.
Romantic comedy ought to have some romance and laughs, but this extraordinarily flat effort has neither.
Somewhere, John Candy and Chris Farley are high-fivin' each other that they died before headlining this stinker.
A quick sweep-up is in order.
It's about time for Cedric the Entertainer to change his name.
Except for a couple of Cedric's ad-libs, which are funnier in the closing-credit outtakes than in the movie itself, the whole thing is just lame and inane.

Director Les Mayfield can only do so much with the anemic, obvious script by Robert Adetuyi and George Gallo. And while his limited action sequences are very solid, this is a comedy, and within it he doesn't do much for his actors.
From past experience, viewers know that Cedric the Entertainer can be very funny. While there are times when Code Name: The Cleaner highlights his comedic abilities, there aren't enough of them.
There are better action scenes in marionette shows.
The Cleaner is an apt title for a Cedric the Entertainer movie because, once again, he's stuck cleaning up the mess some hack screenwriter left him.
Watching Code Name: The Cleaner is like staring into a dark, uneventful abyss.
A bunch of small disasters, collected together and fed to Cedric the Entertainer.
Cedric the Entertainer gets hit on the head and loses his memory in Code Name: The Cleaner, a condition likely to be desired by anyone foolish enough to sit through Les Mayfield's comedy.
This implausible plot full of holes does pave the way for a series of Cedric the Entertainer skits and physical gags. None of these is very funny. A few are painfully unfunny.
If you try to follow the plot, you'll be as confused as Jake is.
Cedric the Entertainer is never going to be Cedric the Leading Man.
Code Name: The Cleaner offers no surprises but is good-natured and funny.
January is usually not the time to expect much high art among new releases, but this is an especially limp star vehicle.
A complete dud.

It's not often that a 90 minute film could lose twenty minutes and still end up with an identical result, but Code Name: The Cleaner does pull that off. If only someone had made [director Les] Mayfield aware of that somewhere along the line.

The Cleaner offers the viewer a dream sequence with Sheridan and Liu fighting in a bubble bath, but in the best Les Mayfield manner, it only lasts for a brief, flickering moment. What isn't over in a moment? The rest of this dud.
Cedric might just want to clean this one right off his resume.
If Cedric The Entertainer keeps making movies like this, The Honeymooners and Johnson Family Vacation, he may really have to work as a janitor.
This dire comedy deserves to be dropped in a vat of solvent to remove its stink.
Before seeing this film I couldn't understand why the producers had given it a subtitle; afterward I realized Ecks vs. Sever was probably the full script.
Director Wych Kaosayananda -- or Kaos, to you -- is stupendously inept, unable even to properly light a combat sequence.
Between explosions there is enough room left for only minimal character development.
For all the sundered families, bereaved mothers and mourning spouses, there's not a shred of genuine feeling in the entire film.
The recut American version is truly awful, but a good 75 percent of the awfulness is attributable to Miramax, the film's distributor.
Nothing's quite so painful as failed comedy, and this atrocity is equivalent to a compound fracture.
The script, by TV writer Wayne Conley, shares some elements with the old Danny DeVito comedy Ruthless People, but humor isn't one of them.
The hokey dialogue and witless physical gags keep everything painful and hectoring.
Formulaic and deeply unfunny.
Baby Geniuses' ramshackle plot serves merely as a launching pad for nearly two hours of jokes revolving around the idea of babies who talk and behave like bad stand-up comedians.
There are ticklish moments, but no real laughs.
A thoroughly misguided, unfunny film.
Christian Slater and Stephen Dorff, the reigning princes of Hollywood schlock, join forces in this brain-dead adaptation of a popular video game.
Excruciating.

Why? Seriously, why? Why would anyone make a sequel to Baby Geniuses, a 1999 film whose existence, from its title on down, appeared to be a cruel joke about the gullibility of the lowest common denominator?
Unspeakably ghastly.
...the filmmakers are so busy churning their not very interesting plot that they forget to let Cedric be funny.
Not nearly bad enough to be truly enjoyable
Cedric the Entertainer's artless performance deadens what could have been a much funnier comedy.
It's Memento for dummies. But to this movie's credit, I couldn't follow it, either.

A faux thriller plot has something to do with a stolen computer chip. The chip isn't the only thing missing from this tepid concoction. You may be hard pressed to find real laughs, with Cedric proving more affable than funny.

The idea is that given the basic premise, the comedian will fill in the gaps with his own bits of business. Cedric is hardly up to the task. Though he's a scene stealer in other people's movies, he relies on tired reactions ("heeellll naw" is his mantra).
There's potential in the story, but who was the casting genius that thought roly-poly Cedric could ever be mistaken for a man of action, or a possible love interest for Lucy Liu?

Cedric the Entertainer doesn't really act here so much as riffs, as if he's working out the kinks in a misconceived stand-up routine. Some of his ad-libs are funny, but you know you're in trouble when the outtakes are funnier than the film as a whole.

The story keeps stopping dead to deliver product placement for Jake's favorite brands of junk food. There must be a better way to work Skittles into the script than to have Jake keep saying things like, 'I love Skittles.'

The story is incidental to the comedy, but it is on the level of humor where the movie completely breaks down. It is almost never funny. Cedric has a few funny scenes, mostly when he is just allowed to joke, with the plot momentarily forgotten.
The good news is, Cedric can make even eating Skittles sort of funny -- and he easily saves this movie from being a wreck.
For its first half-hour, Cedric is the whole show.
It's comedian DeRay Davis and sassy actress Niecy Nash, who earn a few laughs in small supporting roles. Still, any resemblance to real entertainment is strictly coincidental.
The humor is too adult for children and the plot far too childish for most adults; in fact, everything about the film is really too silly to warrant much consideration.

Aside from Cedric's admittedly appealing persona -- he's always watchable, even in dreck like this -- there's absolutely nothing to recommend The Cleaner, not the putative comedy nor the action, which kicks in only at the end.
It's a bad sign for a comedy when viewers are left pining for more ineptly staged shoot-'em-up sequences.

How do films this stale and generic continue to get made, let alone with topflight talent? Cedric has been stealing scenes from bigger names for nearly a decade; he deserves better than a few amusingly-improvised minutes at the end of his own movie.
I'm sure by May Encore will be broadcasting it ten or so times in row on one of their various channels.

...the comedy half doesn't work without the intrigue half, and director Mayfield doesn't look like he would know intrigue if Martin Scorsese brought it to him wrapped in butcher paper with a bow on top.
[A] cheerfully dumb spy comedy filled with ridiculous stereotypes and plot holes as big as cartoon anvils.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: Not the kind of movie you need to rush out and see, but if you're sitting at home trying to decide between doing your own cleaning and watching The Cleaner, I'd pick the movie.
An exercise in robotic filmmaking.
No one expects much from movie adaptations of TV shows but complete incoherence and boredom is a bit too much to bear.
This thriller seems most interested in lingering over battered and bloodied male faces.
George W. Bush in the flesh would have been much funnier than this movie's impersonation.
As in most bad thrillers, the number of pointless shocks increases in direct proportion to the drama's decreasing vitality, like defibrilator paddles jolting a dying man.
It's bad in a sickening, disturbing way, with its gratuitous mixture of sex and violence.
How do films like these get made for video, let alone the wide theatrical run?
Half Past Dead may be the year's funniest unintentional comedy for its inane plot, repetitive, unimaginative stunts and dreadful dialogue.
The title of this dismal action flick refers to the Seagal character's having suffered a near-death experience, though he's returned from the other side with a remarkable lack of insight.
This 117-minute adaptation of an 800-page SF adventure for teenagers seems like a miscalculation on multiple levels.
Cedric's style of humor seems to be stating the obvious, but doing it really fast. He mumbles out loud and makes lame observations.
...I humbly submit that Cedric the Entertainer be required to give up the "Entertainer" portion of his nom de plume until he actually starts entertaining us.
Because of its clever story, funny leading man and two gorgeous supporting actresses, 'Code Name: The Cleaner' is a welcome January surprise.
Hollywood certainly didn't waste anytime in turning out its first insulting blaxploitation flick of 2007.
Don't come looking for a story -- this is a hunt.
Horrendous dialogue and horrific directing dominate this thriller, in which Coleman's performance shines by default.
A country-club member takes a club employee under her wing in this cagey formula thriller that exploits homosexuality better than murder-mystery clues.
Every joke is stretched to the breaking point, and no one seems to be having any fun.
...yet another brainless, utterly disposable thriller geared exclusively towards teenagers...
Get Lucy Liu better roles!
...it's not merely that the script is a sloppy, by-the-numbers action farce; it's more the leaden hand of director Les Mayfield...
Cedric and Lucy Liu...may want to give their agents a good talking-to.
Even as a comedy all of this begs credulity.

It's almost hard to believe that this bland, fluffy, two-generational chick flick is helmed by the same director who 20 years ago gave us Heathers, one of the brightest and sharpest femme-driven high-school satires.
Well, you really can't expect much from comedies this time of year.
This is the kind of movie where everyone looks like they are having a lot more fun than the audience.
Thankfully, at 90 minutes, Epic Movie is anything but epic. Unfortunately, there is little else to be thankful for in Friedman and Seltzer's latest and most meagre lampoon.
you won't miss much if you give this one a pass
The talented comedian mugs his way through an utterly deflated film.
The outtakes in the closing credits were the funniest parts of the movie.
In this latest and tiredest Friedman/Seltzer puff piece the law of diminishing returns persists.

Friedberg and Seltzer are nothing if not intrepid and they jump right into his Willy Wonka and his Captain Jack Sparrow, landing with such a leaden thud that they should be nursing their wounds for the rest of their lives.
Pity [the producers] couldn't find anything funny to do once they'd built the sets, and found dead ringers for Anna Paquin, Paris Hilton, P. Diddy and Jack Black.

None of it makes much sense and none of its funny, and to see such truly talented performers like Coolidge, Willard and Kid-in-the-Hall Kevin McDonald, who appears briefly as a seedy, middle-aged Harry Potter, is merely depressing.

too simple, too vulgar and too obvious to be Funny Movie. It's not even Chuckle Movie or Giggle Movie. It's in your face, with most humor centered around taking characters you recognize and just making them dumber
One of those throw-everything-at-the-screen-and-see-if-anything-sticks movies...In this case, nothing does...All terrible--puerile, vulgar and unfunny.
Because nothing in the universe is funnier than watching Jack Sparrow or Willy Wonka break out into hip-hop gyrations.
On January 26th, I have witnessed what is assured to be the worst film I will behold all year.
What was the last studio picture this bad? Maybe 2002's The Adventures of Pluto Nash. I've seen more talent in my cat's last dump.
Thankfully, the crude, scatological parody Epic Movie, unlike the movies it sends up, is short.
Bad taste and worse jokes abound. Epic Movie's humor isn't tired; it's comatose.
Extravagantly [expends] elaborate sets, special-effects, music, costumes and actor look-alikes for the sake of a few lame gags and a legion of crotch-kicks.
At times there is no visible difference between this and the fictitious film ***, the two-hour, single-take, Academy Award-winning shot of a flatulent gluteus maximus from Mike Judge's Idiocracy.
... this falls well short of the Buffy-level resonances at which [Harlin] was presumably aiming.
It's generally considered bad form for a critic to advocate the kidnap and torture of specific filmmakers, but I'll tell you this: If you did it, and you confessed to me, no way would I turn you in.
Can a picture really be considered a parody if it merely parrots rather than satirizes its source material?
Look what happens without the Wayans brothers' pens.
What makes Epic Movie such an unpleasant endurance test isn't its rampant stupidity or slavish reliance on crude humor--it's the sheer laziness on display throughout.
Unfortunately, this film fell flat and its filmmakers seem to have lost the ability to translate the humor in a satirical way.
Stay home. Because I said so.
Welcome to the rom-com in the age of Must Love Dogs.

Satire points up and emphasizes truths that have gone unnoticed, punctures pretension and tweaks the self-important. Audiences laugh at the unexpected revelation of truth. Epic Movie does none of that.
Writer-directors Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer seem to think a half-baked imitation of the original constitutes instant comic gold.

Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer must be stopped. For the last 10 years, this filmmaking team has created a series of spoof movies so feeble, shoddy and unfunny that they may be part of a diabolical, Manchurian Candidate-like plot.

What you miss most is the shamelessness and wit that Anna Faris and Regina Hall have brought to four installments of Scary Movie. In lieu of those two, there are exploding pimples, a tongue frozen on a pole, and industrial-strength projectile.
The cinematic equivalent of a tapeworm, this delivers few laughs beyond the initial chuckles of recognition.
The real problem with Epic Movie is that while it does a decent job imitating films, it never bothers to make fun of or have fun with them.
I've always loved parody. It's too bad that garbage like this is what passes for it these days.
You know a movie parody is in trouble when you can't quite figure out the frame of reference for the parody.
The film never becomes anything of its own, however; it merely jumps from spoof to spoof, often with tenuous transitions.
The latest spoof from knucklehead screenwriting team and first-time directors Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer.
Epic Movie strays so far from the solid fundamentals of filmmaking that it calls the very foundation of humor into question.
An amateur-hour game of Spot That Reference, intended for people who crack up simply at the mention of anything topical.
Everything you loved about the past couple of years' blockbusters, only much less entertaining and with a lot more urination.

How can you make fun of such self-aware subjects as Borat or Johnny Depp's winkingly fey Jack Sparrow? Who hasn't already noticed Tom Hanks' bad Da Vinci Code hair? And really, is there anything left to say about Samuel L. Jackson and those snakes?
The makers of Epic Movie have just discovered the existence of urine, vomit and pimples, and declared them hilarious.
Woefully unimaginative, obvious and numbing...Epic Movie is lazy and toothless in its inability to satirize material that doesn't need the hysterical microscope.
It's appropriate that much of Because I Said So is set in a bakery, because even in a sea of awful chick flicks, this appalling confection takes the cake.
An unbelievable mess.
The entire project seems like a diabolical conspiracy to destroy one of the few icons we've got left, but luckily that's where it fails most of all.
The premise . . . isn't particularly innovative. It is, however, stretched paper thin with characters whose only allegiance to consistency is getting through the uniformly unfunny joke at hand
Relentlessly exhaustive, simple-minded, unoriginal and inconsequential Because I Said So seems very disconnected in its bid for cockeyed conviction.
Everything about Because I Said So screams out generic chick flick -- and we do mean scream, literally -- from the forgettable title to the excruciatingly corny ending.
...appears to have been made from the parts of other films...
If you're attracted to the classic fairy tale of the young maiden torn between the prince & the pauper and you don't mind a racy modern update to it, you'll have a blast.
The screenplay for Because I Said So may be short on invention but it is large on heart.
Keaton gives a manic, slapstick performance that alternates between being merely bad and being embarrassingly bad. Her work has an unbearable finger-across-the-blackboard effect.
Despite all the scatological high jinks on display, most of the satire is affectionate rather than merciless.
There's not a member of the cast who isn't better than this premise or its execution.
...Keaton kneads the part until it begins to resemble a human being.
Avoid the movie so you won't waste 90 minutes of your life on an unfunny, derivative mess.
[An] obnoxious, headache-inducing horror show.
It's a perfect title for a film so utterly lacking in worthwhile qualities that there is no logical reason to actually see it.
Keaton may well be the only actress in Hollywood who could play this character without making her despicable or treacly.
Throughout most of her career Diane Keaton has shown sound instincts, so it's a mystery why she failed to sniff this false, brittle comedy out as a waste of her gifts.

Because I Said So is a work of comic desperation, and an especially cruel betrayal of Keaton, who looks radiant in her 60s yet keeps finding herself cast in roles that use her age as the foundation for cut-rate slapstick.
Speaking as a longtime Keaton fan, it's hard watching her go through this overbearing mother phase.
The brain recoils at even having to recount the ill-conceived plot.
The only thing you can't fault in Because I Said So is Keaton's integrity, as she commits herself completely to a disastrous role.
Diane Keaton deserves so much better.
Lehmann must've hoped Keaton's appealing daffiness would offset the character's repulsive behavior, but it doesn't.
I spent the bulk of the running time thinking of creative ways for the characters to be murdered.
The only good use for Because I Said So would be as a step-by-step handbook on how not to make a romantic comedy.
A gruesome chick flick with a good performance by Mandy Moore and terrific music that has been relegated to the background.
Because I Said So is a movie about people we don't like doing things no one would ever do.
The worst date movie since Saw III.
A shallow rom-com that's not just eager but frantic to please.
What the filmmakers try to play for laughs isn't funny, it's creepy.
Wince-inducing.
The whole movie feels pushy.
It's barely February, but it's hard to imagine how the movie year could possibly produce a more annoyingly stupid movie.
A depressing example of what passes for a 'woman's picture' in a not exactly woman-friendly media era.
If these are the only kinds of roles we can conceive for actresses who have grown into their faces, as Keaton has, it's no wonder so many younger performers are seeking the knife.
scattershot and misbegotten by even normal romantic comedy standards

Apparently retrieved from a dumpster, labeled "Rejected Sitcom Brain Farts," at the Universal back lot and Scotch-taped back together, the screenplay can only be described as a crime against moviegoers worldwide.
...Keaton [delivers] a painfully over-the-top, tic-ridden performance...
You get what you expect with some funny scenes, a couple of make-you-weep scenes and plenty of female bonding.
Because ends up a joyless, patronizing, and obnoxious 100-minute-long commercial for matricide.
The film contains no laughs, no purpose, and no entertainment.
this film is like Kevin Federline at the guidance counselor's office - it just has no direction
Because I Said So is an exercise in deliberate mediocrity, with chuckles and heartwarming moments distributed as carefully as nuts in a factory-made brownie.
An exercise in canned cuteness.
Do mothers really ask their daughters about orgasms?

Keaton capably pulls off even the silliest slapstick... (but) practically everything in 'Because' is spelled out in the simplest terms, set in bold typeface and then marked with a highlighter pen, lest we miss the meaning.
A predictable, strident and unfunny mass of clich√©s.
BECAUSE I SAID SO is undone by its uneven screenplay
Ultimately, even a vivacious Diane Keaton can't make a familiar film feel fresh -- no matter how hard she tries.
Every clich√© that's ever been in a romantic comedy appears tossed into Because I Said So and delivered by very unfunny actresses.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: My mom said I should save my money and catch this on video later.
Because I Said So exasperates because even its best intentions are phony.
The line between hysterical and hysterics is a thin one, and, although it has its funny moments, for the most part the tone and timbre of Because I Said So falls soundly on the wrong side.
Keaton is almost unwatchable in embarrassing scenes that involve an over-the-top car chase and a computer with a mind of its own.
It's a shame, because pop star Moore continues to prove herself an adept actress.
I am about to issue a declaration that amounts to blasphemy among many film critics, fashionistas and women of a certain age: I am so over Diane Keaton.
The cake that lands in Keaton's face isn't the only confection that turns up in this movie about the romantic life of a caterer, but there's nothing genuinely sweet about it.
It's safe to say that it wastes the talents of a good cast -- one that definitely deserves better than this.
What makes this seem sad instead of simply silly is the way Keaton throws herself into this slop.
There are lots of cakes involved in the film, and each time one shows up you know it's likely to be thrown, fallen on, dropped or pressed into someone's face.
The result is a 105-minute cringe-a-thon that reduces the Katharine Hepburn of her generation to a sitcom harpy presiding over a brood of Valley Girl chicks.
My motherly advice is: Skip it.
One of those rare movies that is so fantastically, fabulously bad, so bursting full of putrid dialogue and appalling scenes, that it becomes worth seeing as some sort of artifact of horribleness.
Diane Keaton should stay away from such derivative, degrading roles.
It's still no fun to watch one of our best veteran film actresses flailing so much.

The search for true love is the backbone of romantic comedy as well as the lifeblood of match.com, but this film's clumsy, completely inauthentic portrayal of it is handled in a shockingly tedious fashion.
It could have been an enjoyable light comedy, or a dark tale of obsession, but it doesn't work.

As a member of their generation, and one who considered them among the best actresses of Hollywood's most probing era, I am both cheered and alarmed by the recent spectacles Jane Fonda, Susan Sarandon and Diane Keaton have made of themselves.
Call it a hunch, but I don't think you're going to see a clip from the appalling romantic comedy Because I Said So at this spring's Diane Keaton tribute at Lincoln Center.
The jokes are crude and repetitious.
Any relationship between the world of Because I Said So and actual human behavior is purely coincidental.
The movie plays out like a freshman film school project with a big budget; it's very pretty to look at and every plot twist is telegraphed with painful precision.
There's not a scene in its ode to dating-quota acceptability and capitalist victory that isn't awful.
There's a charming bonhomie among the sisters, and there are cute touches to the romances.

Every year Hollywood trots out a movie like this on Super Bowl Weekend. A movie by, of, and for women. Because I Said So, though, is like the work of some narrow-casting, niche-marketing mad scientist.
Keaton is a national treasure, always worth the visit even when, as is the case of Because I Said So, her movie isn't.
Playing a ditzy control freak of a mother with serious boundary issues, Keaton comes across as such a screeching, flailing flibbertigibbet that you want to give her costars tranquilizer dart guns.
With Keaton in devastating overdrive, Moore can barely exercise her own brand of ginchiness.

Bette Davis and Joan Crawford, when they reached a certain age, played harridans and ax murderers. Diane Keaton has started playing mothers, but, alas, the effect is about the same: She's scary. Very scary.
Spark? Romance? Wit? Nope, sorry.
Diane Keaton has a lot to answer for in her willingness to portray Hollywood's idea of middle-aged womanhood.
What was Diane Keaton thinking when she signed on to play a shrill, off-putting mother whose unbelievable, over-the-top antics are utterly annoying to watch? Even the title is annoying.
It's so derivative, unfunny and thuddingly bad that it's one of the more cringe-inducing movies of a genre chock-full of clunkers.
As almost everyone knows by now, the early part of the year has become a dumping ground for dreadful movies. Still, Because I Said So constitutes unusually toxic waste.
Believe me when I tell you not to see this unless you're subpoenaed. It's that bad!
Diane Keaton's dizzy iconoclast shtick was kind of cute, rather endearing, and even a little feminist 30 years ago. Now it's just nails-on-a-chalkboard obnoxious.
Another example of filmmakers insulting the intelligence of their audience
Definitely not funny, and not appropriate for young teenagers! Yuck!
An hour into the film, my girlfriend leaned over and whispered, "I wish she (Mandy Moore) would just go ahead and punch her mother (Diane Keaton)."
In lieu of plot, it's cluttered with bad driving scenes, dog reaction shots, falling-splat-with-cakes scenes, and watching old movies scenes.

It's almost too much to handle, the filmmakers forcing the talented cast to speak in such rapid-fire cadences a lot of the emotional material inherent in their words can't help but get lost amidst the chaos.
Filled with characters you'd thankfully only find in a bad romantic comedy, Because I Said So is an unbelievable, unenjoyable mess.
Though it is far from perfect, I'm giving it a pass... once you get a little distance from the pandering, the movie kind of takes off.
I kind of felt sorry for Keaton while watching this.
A laugh-deprived misadventure.
The cast is too talented for the likes of this.
Whatever you do, don't go see this movie. Why? Because I said so.
Recycling every cliche in the rom-com handbook, it's clear from the very first that Lehmann has sacrificed his characters on the altar of sappy endings. What a waste -- for everybody.
[A] trite, manipulative, excruciating nightmare of female pyschosis and idiocy presented as feminine adorableness.
An unfunny comedy about an interfering mother and a dysfunctional family that demeans women big time.
Even the film's costume designer makes Keaton look ridiculous which is no mean feat given that she's clothed in the actress's own style.
The story plays out like a really raunchy episode of Petticoat Junction.

Epic Movie is a comedy that is so spectacularly bad in so many ways that it's almost awe-inspiring -- at every point in the film, every creative choice seems to have been made for precisely the wrong reason.
It could be worse, but that's not saying much.
Funnier than Date Movie, not as funny as Scary Movie 4. (Is) a "free" page on MySpace the new indicator that (a film is) pretty cheap all around?
The memory of this movie will have left your brain before you walk out of the theater. If you're lucky.
The result is another opportunity lost.
Ponderous wisecracks and cloak-and-dagger high jinks pass for comic intrigue in this hapless mix of yuks and kicks.
Diane Keaton has delivered many terrific film performances, but her over-the-top work in 'Because I Said So' isn't one of them.

It's inadequate to say that this film stars Keaton; more accurately, it has befallen her, and it's hard to imagine what she did in a previous life to amass such a huge (presumably now resolved) karmic debt.
It would be forgivable if the film was trying to be representative of real life. But it's not.
The only time Keaton is tolerable is when she's not saying anything at all, the result of laryngitis.
seems more of an ode to Paris and Nicky Hilton than a decent vehicle for these sisters
A romantic comedy that will make you hate both romance and comedy... oh, and also women.
Fairly annoying from start to finish, primarily because Keaton is still relying on that ever less-endearing assortment of addlepated antics which won her an Academy Award for Annie Hall back in 1978.
If you don't expect too much of it, you may find yourself pleasantly -- all right, soothingly -- surprised by it.
It is just too bad that the film isn't called Miniscule Movie because that is a better description of this epic-less piece of garbage.
When you start thinking that the Taco Bell pitchwoman is perhaps too good for the material, you know the script has some serious problems.
The days when Woody Allen told Keaton there was nothing wrong with her character that couldn't be cured 'with Prozac and a polo mallet' are long gone here.
It's hard to find a more stalwart movie monster in the last ten years than Keaton, who's gone from a charming neurotic to a cobwebbed, cell-phone-wielding vagina dentata.

The plot is about as revelatory as a bad Hallmark card, and the lowest common denominator humor results in a moviegoing experience that's almost as appealing as having a conversation with my mother about orgasms.

Friedberg and Seltzer are completely tone-deaf when it comes to the art of film parody, conjuring none of the adolescent brilliance of Airplane! or even the good-natured irony of 2001's Not Another Teen Movie.

Because I Said So's biggest sin is that it treats its characters like idiots, with Keaton's Daphne leading the charge. [She's] a woman who apparently makes her living by baking the occasional cake, most of which land on the sidewalk or in her face.
Lehmann manages to give his characters a little bit more personality than is the norm in such movies, but he doesn't bother to hide the contrived paces he puts them through.
A movie that's so bad, it's actually painful to sit through.
Everyone here is a caricature, and the gaps are papered over with hyperactive shtick. I haven't seen so many cakes dropped or smashed since I Love Lucy.
On screen or in real life, meddling moms don't get more neurotically ebullient than Diane Keaton's dessert maven in the regrettable 'Because I Said So.'
The gutter-brow auteurs who helped write the first Scary Movie and created Date Movie milk their lame sketch-comedy minds for yet another punishingly uninspired skewering of Hollywood hits.
...the writers and director go out of their way to make [Diane Keaton] look ridiculous, pathetic and stupid...
Friedberg and Seltzer's most staggering achievement is rendering "Epic Movie" free from laughs.
...another perfect storm of not funny.
Some of the nonsense could be overlooked as part of rom com conventions, but Because I Said So's shrillness makes for an exhausting experience.
Towards the end, the spectacle of Milly faking an orgasm for her mother's edification is, frankly, enough to kill anyone's hopes of romance.
Next to Epic Movie and Date Movie, the Scary Movies are French cuisine.
A bog standard all-girls-together comedy with a decent cast and less impressive characters.
If you're a mother or a daughter some of it may resonate, but how apt that this painful, toothless farce was originally dreamt up at the dentist...
A shocking embarrassment for all concerned, this is a badly written, badly acted and poorly directed mess from start to finish.
Just a few years ago, Keaton played a character who was sexy, funny and intelligent in Something's Gotta Give. This one's more like Something Gave Out.
...a light-hearted and mindlessly engaging time-waster.
A bit like the 'Friends' episode in which Phoebe has to choose between two men, only with Diane Keaton, and fewer laughs.
If there's a worse screenplay in 2007 than this offering from Karen Leigh Hopkins and Jessie Nelson, it'll be written in crayon.
There's a special circle of hell reserved for whoever thought up the moment where Macht tells Moore she smells like "cake batter".

At one point Daphne warns Milly, "You're going to end up like some pathetic character in a Tennessee Williams play." If ever a film could have used a character from a Tennessee Williams play, it's this one.
Treats women like idiots and men like inflatable sex toys.
Laughter is largely absent from this sorry, shrieking mess.
I've been giving it a great deal of thought and come to the conclusion that the squandering of Diane Keaton's screen legacy is without parallel in the annals of cinema.

A desperate comedy whose frequently acute insights into tense, but loving mother-daughter relationships is constantly hamstrung by ill-advised forays into physical humor and too much reliance on Diane Keaton's mania.
With very little rewriting and a different director in charge, Because I Said So could have been retooled as a horror thriller. ... That version probably would have been funnier, too.
Epic in its crapness.
The most excruciating, unfunny film you'll see this year... if not your entire lifetime.
As well as providing lifestyle porn, the many scenes set in stylish kitchens mean there is usually a cake on hand for somebody to be splattered with. That's the level of the bland attempts at comedy.
In this unwatchable romantic comedy from director Michael Lehmann Diane Keaton plays Daphne Wilder, an inept mother of three pretty but not-believable-as-siblings daughters.
I hated this movie. I think it's the worst performance of Diane Keaton's career.
[A] better movie might have surfaced if everyone had taken their Ritalin and calmed down.
Desperately unamusing comedy that lurches clumsily from one tedious spoof to the next, under the mistaken impression that just referencing a film is enough to get laughs.
At 61, Diane Keaton is still doing her ditzy, girlish thing, but the act is getting a little oppressive and rarely more so than in Because I Said So, an indulgent comedy.
From its weak premise to its boring action to its unpleasant jokes, this movie fulfills the worst expectations of January releases: it's awful.
Completely lacking the wit and charm that made superhero family flicks like The Incredibles and Sky High so entertaining, Zoom is an absolute mess of a movie.
Haylie and sister Hilary Duff just don't have the comedy stylings to sell this half-baked story of heiress sisters battling to save their dad's cosmetics empire from ruin.

"This thing is screwier than Courtney Love!" whimpers Hilary in her usual chihuahua-on-helium whine. Even she, however, manages to shine next to her aggravating older sister, saddled as she is with all the comic timing of a mortally wounded elephant.
Messy, patronising and tonally confused, this vanity project - timed to co-incide with Hilary Duff's perfume launch - quite frankly stinks.
There's nothing even remotely entertaining about this film -- audiences should stay home and play the original (or one of its numerous sequels) on Playstation instead.
Beyond such amateurishly ill-constructed plot points, what should be a fast-moving film is slow and repetitious.
Watchable enough and by no means as bad as The Perfect Man, although there's not much here that'll interest the over-12s.

I don't think anyone actually wrote Because I Said So; I think that some Hollywood artificial intelligence think-tank instead fed DVD box sets of The Gilmore Girls and Sex and the City into a computer, along with Pottery Barn catalogs for roughage. ...
There's more than enough material here to make an enjoyable drama about a mother and her adult daughters. But the writers and director fail on virtually every front.
The title describes the sound that you should make in your car, or on foot, or on mule, heading away from any cinema showing this film.
The film's sole purpose is to promote, with chilling lack of irony, Hilary Duff's own brand of perfume -- oh, and there's her single as well.
The production values are above par, but as in Carpenter's original, seeing ghosts is less scary than imagining them.

William Malone's fear dot com desperately wants to be a cutting-edge chiller with its 'up-to-the-minute' internet theme, but turns out to be a depressing up-chuck of every great horror movie of the last 20 years.

The script from first-timers Paul Kimatian and Christopher Gambale requires Dillon to say corny things like: 'Bricks don't fall outta the sky in this neighborhood unless I'm throwin' 'em.' Tony Soprano, he ain't.
Slow-motion shots of swaggering tough guys punctuate this painfully hackneyed gang drama set in late-50s Brooklyn.
Just when you thought camp was dead, along comes this bizarre cross between a Tarantino knockoff and a Hammer horror film.
A sizeable amount of the budget for this lazy film must have been spent on ammunition.
each character in the film is so shallow and cold that there's nobody for the audience to cheer on.
A documentary on baseball's Texas Rangers and their last-place season would have been more interesting.
There's some pretty good improvised shtick from DeRay Davis as a wacky janitor. But these are small pleasures in a movie that never really generates any serious laughs.
Under the circumstances, Anjelica Huston and Lukas Haas manage not to embarrass themselves, but only because they're pretending to be in a different movie.
... Mike Myers has already milked this type of gag-dense character comedy bone dry.
Apart from Jon Voight, slumming and turning in a rather droll, if lonely, performance as the German-accented villain, the movie amounts to cynical, cutesy claptrap.
[It] made me laugh. I don't know why.
A Duff movie indeed.
It seems a shame to waste any of these actors on a movie with no higher aspirations than educing a few second-rate chills.
The kind of comedy that you'll forget mere moments after seeing.
Redline is the kind of movie where they spent so much on the fast cars they forgot to save any for acting lessons or screenplay rewrites.
Redline is a direct-to-knucklehead release that refuses to bow out gracefully.
The pic oozes the charm and personality of an industrial film.
Redline continues the mind-boggling trend of films that choose to justify their existence by piling on layer after layer of meaningless excess.
You could watch it with the sound off and the plot wouldn't make any less sense than it does with it on.
Do yourself a favor and stay home. Griffin's 21-second wrecking-the-Enzo video on YouTube is more exciting (and better directed, and better acted ...) than anything in Redline.

Although the movie's artistic merits are virtually nonexistent, Sadek does understand his audience, most of whom are unlikely to be acquainted yet with two key aspects of the film: driver's licenses and women.
Everything you'd expect it to be, and yet so much less: less character development, less believability, and most unforgivably, less escapist entertainment.
Redline mostly feels like one long stunt intercut with the boring parts of a porn movie.
The makers of this self-indulgent autopalooza take a Ferrari engine, Porsche speed, Mercedes horsepower, and a Shelby Mustang chassis and somehow combine them into a Yugo.
Redline isn't exactly a car wreck, mainly because it's far less exciting and you can, in fact, look away.
The movie Redline is all about surfaces, for young men with testosterone to burn.
The cars in the film are treated with more respect than the women.
Looks like a music-video without the music--sleek visuals, lots of things moving around the screen, girls posing, and guys dressed like it's the 1980s. Steer clear.
It's hard to say whether gleaming automobiles or women's bodies are given the more fetishlike treatment in this vanity production.
Well...at least you can look at the cars.
click to read review (though I have no idea why you'd want to)
Yawn.

A PG-13 celebration of hot chicks, fast cars, and deplorable behavior is like diet Mountain Dew, near-beer, or an expletive-free version of Straight Outta Compton -- a tame, watered-down version of the real thing.
Code Name: The Minstrel Coon Show!

An idiotic action thriller, vanity project and testosterone-filled guilty pleasure whose sole purpose is to show off a fleet of million-dollar Ferraris and Lamborghinis belonging to fledgling movie mogul Daniel Sadek.
This is one of those movies in which virtually no one comes out unscathed.
...a rather silly and humorless affair that pretty much wastes Cedric's comic talents.
The movie would play almost as a postmodern parody of 1960s drive-in fare if it weren't put forward with such a silly straight face.
Kennedy seems to think that simply showing up in Hammer pants is enough to make the movie work.
The climax set at the dancing competition drags on so long one wonders if the film wasn't originally meant to be a miniseries event.
If you know Jamie Kennedy's work then you know what to expect - a half assed, earnest effort that will trot out some tired jokes and eventually run out of steam.
Like Norbit, Kickin' It Old Skool is a film unable to provide its charmingly stupid characters with the movie they truly deserve.
It's horrific to watch Kennedy and his cast not even care about what they're putting out into the world. People, we're getting closer to Ow! My Balls! every day.

A light-weight comedy about mothers and daughters, Because I Said So is a bit like the chocolate souffl√©s that Mandy Moore's Milly cooks throughout. It's light and fluffy, but on occasions it does not rise to the occasion
Kickin' It Old School is actually much more amusing than it has a right to be, considering that you know exactly what's coming.
I hope Jamie Kennedy has a huge fan base because I can't see anyone else paying hard-earned money to sit through this.
This cruddy-looking, Rip Van Winkle-esque slough through 1980s-era pop culture detritus joins an already crowded field of contenders for Razzie recognition at year's end.
An inauspicious feature debut for director Harv Glazer and all three scenarists, the Big-meets-breakdancing comedy will be kickin' it to ancillary by swimsuit season.
Jamie Kennedy may be becoming the new Pauly Shore...ineptitude marks every aspect of the writing and execution.
Each lame-duck gag hits the screen with an audible thud before the director decides to point his camera at something even less amusing.
Kennedy believes he is one of those performers whose every move is funny, who can keep an audience in stitches simply by falling down or looking confused. He is mistaken.
High-concept comedy, bottom of the barrel execution.
Jamie Kennedy ought to let a bomb-sniffing dog check out scripts for him.
Kickin' It Old Skool is probably as tolerable as it can be for a comedy with no obvious creative aim.
About eight minutes of this comedy is devoted to some terrific breakdancing; the rest consists of wall-to-wall product placement and politically incorrect bad-taste comedy.
When Jamie Kennedy wakes up from 20 years in a coma and still thinks he's in the 1980s, the results are kind of funny -- for about 5 minutes.
Yeah, the plot is cheesy, but I like Velveeta every now and then.
This ostensible comedy may be a new depths-of-hell low in the Emmanuel Lewis filmography, but for star Jamie Kennedy it's par for the coarse.
The film itself seems lost in a time warp -- even its attitude toward the '80s is out of date considering the ongoing revival in music and fashion from that era.
As appealing as acid-washed jeans.
A pathetically unfunny comedy that should have been shipped straight to video, if not recycled as guitar picks.
Laugh proof and choreographically blah.
Adults old enough to appreciate the choice electro-boogaloo soundtrack and get the 'Mr. Roboto' jokes will doubtless find the rest of it painfully dumb.
Despite some legitimately entertaining dance sequences, no amount of parachute pants can disguise the fact that Kickin' is a very stupid movie, with many more failed jokes than successful ones.
You might think that after Kennedy proved capable of emptying every theater in the civilized world with his last two vehicles someone would have said, 'Enough!' But no.
It's a lame duck of a film.
Although technically a coming-of-age film, Kickin' It is, in every way, regressive.
Kickin' It Old Skool equates making incalculable 80s pop culture references with joke telling.

The writers make sure to fill their script with only the most obvious jokes and cultural references so that their star's particular comedic talents will shine brightest and he can work his magic without the risk of causing any audience members to think.
...a little of [Jamie Kennedy] goes a long way; a lot goes nowhere.
The funniest thing about Kickin' It Old Skool, yet another in a long line of not particularly funny Kennedy movies, is how little we actually have advanced since the '80s.
After cringing through Son of the Mask in 2005, I was convinced that trying to be funny could not get any worse for Jamie Kennedy. ... I was wrong that things couldn't get worse.
Kennedy has gone from a somewhat promising young actor to a crowd repellent.
More a string of already-past-their-expiration-date gags based on big popcorn flicks than an actual film.
Unfunny, unlikeable and unnecessary, "Kickin' It Old Skool" is one of the lamest so-called comedies to limp on to the screen in years.
Forced to endure such casually offensive nonsense, the viewer ends up slumming it far more than the duff protagonists.
...juvenile at best and flat-out lame at worst...
Kickin' It Old Skool aspires to be Big with break dancing, but it falls flat on its spinning head. Even the break dancing gets tired fast, making the film even more tedious to get through.
Go rent Blazing Saddles instead.

If Cedric the Entertainer's constant mugging for the camera is not your cup of tea, and a derivative plot, relatively humorless script, and mundane directing aren't up your alley, then best to clean Code Name: The Cleaner off your must-see list right now.
There's very little that's Epic about Epic Movie. While the film has plenty of fun, it's little more than a late-night comic sketch stretched to feature length.
So concerned is the film with contriving at least one gratuitous jump-fright every five minutes that elements like character and story soon become lost in the fog.
This movie is like a sneeze of bad jokes splattering its germs into the air we all breathe.
It's a horror film for the MTV generation, a horror film for the audience of "Laguna Beach"...
There may be a lot of comedy potential in someone from the '80s waking up in the new millennium, but the writers of Kickin' It Old Skool are fairly oblivious to it.
Even the geography of the film doesn't seem to make sense.
The fight scenes are the worst kind of editing-room cheating, meant to cover for actors who haven't been trained to wield anything more intimidating than a cell phone.
A folly so supreme that it occasionally inspires awe, in the sense that so many people spent so much time and money on it without ever realizing how awful it is.

Bolero must rank as one of the worst major movies ever made. Many awful movies are at least funny in a campy sort of way. Bo and John Derek, however, make films so sincerely bad that they offer nothing in the way of relief.
Matricide.
Daddy Day Camp suffers all the near-classic sequel handicaps.
Poison ivy would be less painful.
If you were alive and watching TV during this decade, you'll find something to give you a smirk
The minstrelsy of Gooding Jr.'s performance is abhorrent but no more offensive than the showboating that won him the Oscar.
Memo to Cuba: if you're offered the lead in a sequel to Murphy's Pluto Nash, say no.
The actors obviously see the movie only as a paycheck, but the check should have a note at the bottom that says, 'Shame on you!'
A lazy, juvenile, starkly unfunny and consistently unrelatable family film.
Gates and Rae are game, but not funny in the least. The kids are stereotypes, and not particularly amusing ones.
By now you've seen most of the visual gags. A bus drives into a building. An outhouse explodes.
The screenplay is attributed to three writers. That means if the film's funny parts were divided evenly among them, they each wrote zero.
A Cuba Gooding, Jr. kind of boyz in the woods career trajectory switch.

The film doesn't need a heartfelt detour, especially any creation that contains a revenge scenario involving a urine-filled water balloon, and it disappoints me that the production didn't have the guts to assemble a more relaxed summer camp farce.
Its humor derives from the campers' toilet and digestive tract malfunctions - truly tedious, except, perhaps, for matinee moppets with indulgent parents.
A lot of wet stuff flies toward the screen and there are many, many intended-to-be-hilarious gags (in both senses of the word) about things that smell bad.
An excruiciating stew of kindergarten-level toilet humor and absurd (and false) sentimentality...
It's gotten to the point where Gooding's presence on a marquee practically guarantees we'll be bashing our heads against the seat in front of us.
If the movie is relentless low-brow swill, its splattery good cheer makes it hard to hate. Just go in expecting the expected, and maybe bring a tarp.
It's a bit sad to see this talented, Oscar-winning actor reduced to taking Murphy's cast-off parts, but Gooding does fine with what the movie gives him.
The antics of cute or precocious children can't save this mess.
This terrible sequel to a bad movie was directed by Fred Savage, the now-grown star of The Wonder Years, though there's no evidence of any behind-the-scenes adult supervision.
Not quite as funny as a perforated ulcer.
Have your little ones already seen Ratatouille and rented Thunderpants?
What's worse than a listless sequel to a terrible movie? How about a listless sequel with a far less interesting cast than the first film.

The film exercises some restraint (by today's low standards, anyway) in its deployment of poop and fart jokes. I counted only two crotch wallops (the new pratfall) and just a single incident of projectile vomiting.

The worst kind of sequel. No original stars or director, just a cobbled-together script by one of the writers of Daddy Day Care. There should have been a big red flag when Eddie Murphy declined to appear.
As one might anticipate with a comedy about children and the outdoors, a lot of screen time is devoted to bodily noises and throwing up.
Daddy Day Camp, a comedy for no ages, has an amazing amount of CGI -- Cuba Gooding Incompetence.
Daddy Day Camp, the unexpected sequel to 2003's barely watchable comedy Daddy Day Care, is superior to its inspiration in one very significant way. It's three minutes shorter.
Predictable as any TV sitcom.

Owes more to the third or fourth sequel to Meatballs and other character-building summer-camp comedies than it does to Daddy Day Care, with neither director Fred Savage or the writers inclined to come up with a single original idea.
Poison ivy jokes. Poop jokes. Runaway bus jokes. Young love jokes. Skunk jokes. Some fake fatherly tender moments. Vomit jokes. This film has them all.
Other than being silly most of the time and stupid on occasion, there is nothing offensive about Daddy Day Camp.
About as much fun as being given a wedgie and hung from the camp flagpole.
Daddy Day Camp is a recruiting poster for kids, insisting that there's no domestic problem that military values can't solve.

The acting is atrocious and more obvious than you see in many high school or college productions. The jokes are stale. The storyline is so predictable, I'll bet nearly everyone in the theater will guess what happens next.
Well, what did anyone expect Daddy Day Camp to be?
Daddy Day Camp should just limp off to the nurse's tent and call it quits.
It's all obtusely broad and ridiculous, and the dreaded 'life lessons' drag it out interminably.
Perhaps a productive use for Daddy Day Camp may be found among death row inmates who wish to make their final minutes feel like weeks.
The script... is a lumpy mess that mixes slapstick potty humor with ponderous father-son confrontation and reconciliation - neither of them staged effectively.
What's great about this hideous, soul-scarring, brain-melting film is that it teaches children that to win at a competition... you must play as dirty as the other team.
A cheesy, abysmal sequel to an entertaining adaptation...
Muddah, Faddah, kindly disregard this fil-m.
One of the most inept movies a Hollywood studio has ever unleashed.
Much time is spent waiting for a methane-filled toilet to explode, an incident that only begins to approximate the visceral experience of watching this movie.
Cuba 'Show me the money!' Gooding, Jr. stars in this utterly predictable, unfunny, infantile test of patience and waste of ninety minutes of my life I can never get back. Show me the exit!
A treacly underdog story with kids who are either stereotypes or miniature adults, with the real adults engaged in bug-eyed mugging and limb-waving that would have been too broad for silent movies.

There's no point being highbrow about a film that relies on the typical fart-puke-nuts-kaboom brand of family comedy, but [director] Savage's lethargic, impersonal approach can't even make Camp's gross-out moments appropriately revolting.
Because he's an Oscar winner with a rep now for headlining turkeys, watching Cuba Gooding Jr. in trash like Daddy Day Camp almost hurts.

The juvenile actors come off as movie brats, and the pacing is slowed by treacly speeches about father-son bonding. As a child star on The Wonder Years, director Fred Savage worked with some of TV's best, but you'd never guess it from this.
This kinder and gentler sequel features the main characters from Daddy Day Care but with a different cast.
An extended sitcom for kids, with very little to entertain adults.

Here's to hoping that the pint-sized thespians who play those kids -- barely blessed with names, let alone personalities -- don't mistake the lame lessons of the adults around them on the set of Daddy Day Camp as a master class in comedic acting.
At least it will not suck anybody's will to live.
A generic time-waster powered by a lazy, cynical combination of scatological kiddie humor and maudlin sentiment.
Lights out.
Daddy Day Camp is a perfect family film for the blind and deaf.
Just horrible.
Doesn't attain the acute awfulness of last week's Bratz -- but also lacks the grim 'end of civilization as we know it' fascination of that discharge of dumbness.
The single punch line that sparks genuine laughter comes three minutes into the film; after that, these marriages are made in comedy hell.
It's mostly just a matter of waiting till feeding time.
Leaden, laden with effects, short on imagination.
Never will you wish more fervently for an Adrienne Barbeau cameo, just for old time's sake. Your prayers will be in vain.
...original stars Eddie Murphy and Jeff Garlin have wisely chosen to be absent this time around.

Gooding would rather mug for the camera than actually act. The film's young stars don't have the talent to be cast in a fifth grade Christmas pageant. And the script is uninspired and lacking a single bit of humor.
If you like your outhouse humor explosive then this "'Camp"'s for you!
While Danica McKellar is busy extolling the virtues of mathematics to young females of America, her erstwhile leading man Fred Savage can be found toiling for a far less noble cause.
If your idea of fun is an hour and a half surrounded by screaming, whining, vomiting children, then this may be your movie.
Watching children act, when it's bad, is on par with having a tooth pulled; and suffice it to say, the adult acting is not much better.
Whatever happened to Cuba Gooding Jr.'s career?

A veteran of classic films such as Annie Hall and The Godfather, Diane Keaton should have known better than to sign up for this kind of light and fluffy schmaltz, even if the director promised she would look great in her underwear.
while Jamie Kennedy's character of Justin is supposed to be an 11-year-old in a 30-year-old's body, it seems he has suffered irreparable brain damage in his coma
This one is a typical time-waster for teenagers or others with disposable income and underdeveloped taste.
Cruise control indeed, as in slow and phoned-in, coasting by on what is passed off as thrills.
Desperately unfunny, badly written sequel that's essentially a mish-mash of tired cliches, fart gags and genuinely terrible performances. One to avoid.
Worse than you can possibly imagine - no, really!
Daddy D-Day for Cuba's career.
Follow US audiences' lead - pitch your cinematic tent elsewhere.
Never work with children or animals. Unless you're a child or an animal, in which case, never work with Cuba Gooding Jnr.
Criminally lazy follow-up to the syrupy family comedy Daddy Day Care.
An unnecessary and unlovable sequel to the Eddie Murphy vehicle Daddy Day Care, though this time the producers have traded down to Cuba Gooding Jr. Not recommended.
Parents! Hire a bouncy castle. Put on clown paint and make balloon animals. You need not see this.
Mindless auto racing film a drag for teens and up.

If not quite one of the worst sequels ever made, it's near the top of the list of all-time most disappointing sequels. Writer-director Stallone stupidly attempts to turn Tony Manero into a dancing Rocky.
Forgettable camp comedy is fine for kiddie laughs.
Kennedy's lowbrow comedy best for '80s veterans.
This remake exists for no clear reason at all. It doesn't even make sense and the action is dull and repetitive.
I can't think of a single kind word to say about this unfortunate family comedy which is unoriginal, predictable, schmaltzy and bland.
The whole thing is pretty stupid, but Angus Macfadyen is watchable as the villain.
Were the filmmakers really so wedded to every scene they couldn't find 15 minutes to cut? Besides, shouldn't we as a culture being moving on to depleting the comic potential of '90s nostalgia by now?

too clumsy to be the sophisticated parody of memory-loss films it might have been, too bland for its action sequences to kick any ass, too dumbed-down to make much out of the clashes of race, class and gender at the heart of its fish-out-of-water comedy
A prime candidate for Worst Movie Of 2007.
Code Name: The Cleaner is one of the year's big stinkers.
Do anything: rob a petrol station, superglue your eyelids together, chew on broken glass, just avoid at all costs.
where the number-one superguy used to solve crazy mix-ups like this in 15 minutes, The Cleaner takes a laboured, exposition-larded hour and a half.
The sooner Code Name... gets flushed out of cinemas, the better.
Although comprised of lowest-common denominator gags, it's an oddly hard-to-follow affair, with good and bad FBI agents popping up everywhere and the plot only revealing itself in fits and starts.
If you like comedies but hate going to the trouble of actually laughing, then this might just be the movie you've been waiting for.
The one laugh is in the production notes, where director Les Mayfield claims this is a comic take on the Jason Bourne movies. As if.
Depressingly laugh-free comedy that's so irredeemably awful that you'll wonder why Martin Lawrence isn't in it.
The only element this turkey of a bomb of a debacle is missing is Lindsay Lohan.
It's shameful how even when Hollywood looks in novel places for material, the studios manage to make that material mind-numbingly routine.
This is nothing less than bottom-of-the-barrel junk.
For a film like One Missed Call to be frightening or good would have required far more art and intelligence than this shoddy little production could possibly muster.

Call is the first major motion picture release of 2008, in charge of setting the tone for the lengthy year to come. My friends, the future does not look promising. In fact, it feels like a swift kick to the groin.
One missed opportunity.
The hard candies that appear in all the victims' mouths indicate not a terrifying link among them but relief that they died with fresh breath.
And doesn't all of this have a familiar Ringu to it?
If "Mystery Science Theater 3000" were still on the air Tom Servo and his quick-witted robotic friends would be all over this thing.
It's as if Vanilla Ice wrote the script, sampling elements from The Ring and The Grudge with a dash of Pulse sprinkled in.
Borrows so heavily from the corpus of J-horror flicks, and especially Hideo Nakata's, that it should really be titled The Ring Tone.
Takeshi Miike's original 2003 One Missed Call was second-rate techno-phobic J-horror tripe, meaning that Eric Valette's even lousier American remake is something like the next generation of suck.
Pity this most mysterious 'Can you hear me now?' of all is spoiled by too many answers to too many questions.
A film so utterly misbegotten that it almost makes Alien Vs. Predator: Requiem look competent by comparison.
I staunchly refuse to be afraid of my cell phone, or at least if I'm going to be afraid of it, I need better reasons than the ones given in this.
More useless than bad, the type of thing that will divert your attention for an hour and a half but nothing more.
Decent if derivative.
Another mediocre remake of a Japanese horror film in which flashes of computer-generated ghosts are meant to compensate for lousy acting and a banal storyline.
Laughable, not screamable.

Yet another tired, ultimately incoherent horror movie that undoes the promise of its pretty good premise and potentially interesting story structure with dull scares, sloppy ending and a pair of unconvincing, leaden lead performances.
This is one call you should definitely miss.
Plays out just as silly as its premise sounds.
Puerile and low-rent, piggybacking on the fad of updating foreign horror films by dumbing them down for us American simpletons.
As annoying as a busy signal.
Why, after realizing how deadly these calls can be, does every victim still insist on listening to them? Perhaps only the screenwriters know for sure.
While it may be clich√©d to proclaim the original foreign film to be superior, the fact remains that the Japanese pic contains more scares and intended laughs than this slapdash American remake.
About as fresh and vital as a fifth-generation dub of The Star Wars Holiday Special.
The phone terror theme is tired and director Eric Valette's version is even more predictable than the original. If it's going to call itself a horror, then don't make us laugh.
If the first wide release movie of 2008 is an indicator of the kind of year a writers' strike Hollywood has in store, we may all be watching DVDs.

The script appears to blatantly rip-off plot devices and story elements from The Ring, but screenwriter Andrew Klavan avoids plagiarism by tacking on an incomprehensible second ending where Ring would have left off.

The worst part about this movie is that, even though it's impossible to piece everything together logically, it's easy to see where it's going because there's nothing new here. There's a sameness to all these Japanese-turned-American retreads.
Give this call a miss.
A brow-furrowing blend of child abuse and adult trauma, Andrew Klavan's screenplay sacrifices coherence for atmosphere at every turn.
Another demonstration of how certain studios and producers care neither about us nor the skill required to pull off a respectable work of garbage.
One Missed Call doesn't have much style or substance.
Star Ed Burns was fuming over the fact that his movies would be more popular if they featured Mentos dropping into exploding Diet Cokes.
Given all the hoopla over the Apple iPhone, it's a wonder that no one has yet complained over an essential missing feature: It doesn't ring you up to alert you that you are going to die.
The best part of the movie is the fact that, at a running time of an hour and a half, it's mercifully short.
Supernatural horror doesn't have to make sense, but when it tries it shouldn't fail -- as it does in One Missed Call, spectacularly and in thuddingly dull fashion.

Drastically under-produced, One Missed Call is so tedious that Alexander Graham Bell would have difficulty staying awake. Those vigilant Verizon Wireless techies from the commercials would be fired for napping on the job.
If you missed the first One Missed Call, made in Japan in 2004, you now can miss the American remake.
[A lame] attempt to cash in on the same ghost-in-the-machine craze that begat The Ring, The Grudge and Phone.
The direction is uninspired, acting is lifeless, and the script borders on the inept. A PG-13 rating means that it's short on shocks, too.
Borrowing from this bottomless well, perhaps it's best to say that you should hang up, turn off your phone or even cancel your service should this film attempt to reach out and touch you.
Shannyn Sossamon and Edward Burns give performances that qualify as languorous even on the heavily left-shifted bell curve with which we grade horror film acting.
It's always a relief to see Edward Burns in anything he didn't write or direct himself. But just realize: This is the first big release of 2008.
Call's plot is so silly and nonsensical, even the characters have to regularly remind one another what exactly is supposed to be going on.
To redial applicable catchphrases, this garbled American remake of Takashi Miike's already staticky 2004 exercise in J-horror is a wrong number.
When it comes to scary movies, the Japanese have it figured out. Unfortunately, commercial filmmakers in the United States usually don't.
While it does seem entirely likely that prepubescent boys will dig the heck out of this, In the Name of the King ultimately comes off as a pale carbon-copy of the Lord of the Rings series.

quote: ... its 0% Rotten Tomatoes rating is harsh enough to almost make me want to defend it. Almost.
While director Eric Valette fails to do anything with the derivative plot or the interesting cast, he manages an unusual, appealingly quiet tone.
Is this movie so god-awful bad that it's hilariously good? Can't be bothered deciding. Figure that's an answer in itself.

quote: Though Boll now has his own fan base who love his awfulness -- the crowd I saw the movie with cheered when his name came up onscreen at the end -- he isn't consistent enough for my liking/disliking.

Until the mainstream produces some films undeserving of idiot violation, the idiot violation represented by Meet the Spartans -- a Xerox of absolute zero -- will be par for the course.
Speaking of YouTube, let me save you 65 minutes. Go to the website, type in United 300, and see a far funnier, far more clever 300 spoof that's only five minutes long. From last spring.

Writer-directors Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer basically reprise the tired formula from their earlier efforts, which is to throw in as many pop culture references as possible to cover up the lack of any real wit.
It's only about an hour and a quarter long, although a closing dance number stretches it out another few minutes. Brevity, it turns out, is also the soul of stupidity.
Meet the Spartans is a downtrodden cinematic vacuum—a sickening, derivative, shallow, condescending, utterly worthless piece of ....
What's the point of making a parody that's dumber than the stuff it parodies?
Lazy, lame and painfully unfunny.
Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, the team behind Meet the Spartans, prove that ridiculing other movies is much easier than making your own.
You could teach a college course on what not to do in a comedy by showing Meet the Spartans.

While there's enough comedic material there for as many as three somewhat tolerable minutes of MADtv, Meet The Spartans gamely alternates between unfunny gay jokes and violent pratfalls for a good 80 minutes.
Is its purported idiocy put to a worthwhile use, or is this just another stale retreat of MADtv?
Don't expect anything of depth and you won't be disappointed by this predigested pabulum.
It aims to be a so-called spoof of 300 but only succeeds at being a commercial for idiocy.
Witlessly crude and vulgar - it's my first Worst Movies of 2008 contender.
At the risk of praising with faint damning, Meet the Spartans isn't the worst film I've ever seen; however, I'm not suggesting that this feature-length parody of 300 is good in any way.
Clocking in around 69 minutes total, Meet the Spartans is not a movie. All involved should feel slightly ashamed.
It's mind-boggling to imagine that this witless, amateurish mess came from supposedly professional writers and directors.
If you part ways with $12 for a ticket to see this thing -- that's before parking and popcorn -- you're barking mad.
It's a MADtv or Saturday Night Live sketch dressed up in feature-length clothing. It's way too much of an OK thing. And the way-too-much-ness goes on and on.
It's so bad even Carmen Electra should be embarrassed.

Inane comedies can be fun when done well, but bad inane comedies are simply embarrassing. You feel pity for the actors making fools of themselves, and flabbergasted that a studio probably passed on making so many other more worthy projects instead.
Dumb, raunchy comedy is a tired spoof attempt.
I'm moving to Europe.
Messrs. Friedberg and Seltzer make their annual locust-like descent on theaters leaving a trail of ruthlessly murdered brain cells in their wake.

A nearly plotless and always asinine stoner comedy that is so inconsequential it begins to evaporate from the memory before it is even over.

I half expected to see the spoof-making team in direct address, explaining the supremacy of the tentpole uber-alice, perhaps while backed by Emperor Palpatine.

Seldom has a pic been more appropriately titled than Disaster Movie, yet another frantically unfunny free-form farce from the unfortunately prolific writing-directing team of Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer.
No one expects sophisticated wit from this type of movie, but would it be too much to ask for more than a chuckle every 10 minutes?

Having to watch and review 'Disaster Movie' must be payback for the juvenile pranks I took part in as a teenager.

Cobbled together with plotlines, characters, catchphrases and other assorted gimmicks still lodged in the short-term memory cavities of our pop cultural consciousness.

The Haunting of Molly Hartley flirts with having something to say about budding female sexuality and evangelical religion, but it winds up being a pale copy of several of Roman Polanski's more chilling films.

For those who find bloody noses and whispered voices bone-chilling, heeeeeeere's The Haunting of Molly Hartley.
High school horror flick more dreary than spooky.
The cinematic equivalent of a razor blade hidden in an apple.

The story's a snooze, so the filmmakers punch it up with smash cuts and thunderclaps that turn the most laughably banal items into cheap jack-in-the-box shocks. They'll make you flinch -- but then again, so will most of the dialogue.

This is a prime example of horror conceived by people who don't know the genre, for people who don't like horror films. Practically nothing here is interesting, involving, or new, and, worst of all, it isn't even entertaining as pure kitsch.
I've read fortune cookies that were scarier, not to mention smarter and more interesting.
The Haunting of Molly Hartley' left me as disappointed as a youngster who receives a box of raisins at every house on his/her trick-or-treat route.
As it races from one unlikely trauma to the next for poor Molly, the movie forgets one key thing: The devil is in the details.
It's no Rosemary's Baby, but for teens looking for a quick fix on All Hallow's Day, it will do.
It would take hallucinations of a powerful kind indeed to find anything worthwhile in The Haunting of Molly Hartley, a dead-on-arrival thriller that resolutely fails to come to life.
It's a horror film better suited for skittish cats than humans.
God and Satan duke it out for the soul of a young girl in The Haunting of Molly Hartley, an unexpectedly cynical addition to the teen-scream genre.
The Haunting of Molly Hartley isn't the least bit haunting. It's just cheap.
If you get past the retro Nancy Drew title, this is a worthwhile effort.

The Haunting of Molly Hartley, sort of an updated Rosemary's Baby for teens, sucks most of the suspense out of its own suspense-thriller before the story even gets going.

...an entirely forgettable (and utterly lightweight) horror endeavor.
Poorly directed by Joseph Sargent, who relies heavily on blood and fast editing to create tension since there certainly isn't any written into the script.

One nagging point: Pic seems aimed at kidvid market, but it revels in its ongoing references to open sexuality, including a reprise of opening credits that run over a microscopic view of squirming sperm. Very tasteful.

While formulaic and predictable, the parallel human and animal plots offer enough dream sequences, guest star appearances, musical interludes and holiday spirit to keep both children and adults moderately entertained.
It all amounts to an embarrassing show of unrestrained, Hollywood-style egomania.
Tracking Travolta's adventures as he gets to perform on Broadway and falls in and out of love, director Stallone is in his mindless mode when it comes to characterization.

There's really nothing here you haven't seen before, except maybe the sight of John Travolta walking around with tubes in his nose.

Pacing leaves a lot to be desired and the moment-of-attack sequences, full of jagged cuts and a great deal of noise, more closely resemble the view from inside a washing machine.
Pretty much the Showgirls of sci-fi shoot-'em-ups.

Universal took a step in the right direction by whittling Problem Child down to just 81 minutes but didn't go far enough. The studio should have excised another 75 minutes and released this unbelievable mess as a short.
By turns pointless and pointlessly mean-spirited.
[A] relentlessly adolescent romantic comedy.
After watching Strange Wilderness, you may want to soak your feet in a tub of live piranhas, just for laughs. You'll find it a lot more fun than anything in this movie.

"Battlefield Earth," based on a crappy 1982 sci-fi novel by cult religion dips#*t L. Ron Hubbard, is so inept and pathetic that it should forever end any questions about the validity of Hubbard's manufactured religion of Scientology.
Proof that most sequels should be avoided, "The Whole Ten Yards" vaporizes the humor of its superior 1999 precursor.
Director Renny Harlin ("The Long Kiss Goodnight") phones in this thoughtless teen horror flick from screenwriter J.S. Cardone ("The Forsaken").
Even though the plot forgoes the formulaic slam-dunk, hackneyed devices, low production values, and the stilted direction (by Preston A. Whitmore II) dribble the ball off the shoe and out of bounds.

The reunion of the multi-ethnic Funky Fresh Boys triggers a fusillade of un-PC misfires as the not-so-fab four try to alleviate their personal woes by entering an American Idol-esque dance-troupe contest.
It plays out like an overlong Comedy Central skit lurching for the next laugh without any remorse for the gross misfires in between.
[An] unbewitching brew of clich√©s.

It's all reasonably pleasant to watch, but Isacsson doesn't seem to know what to do with the story once Al and Imogen fall in love.
Pitched halfway between legitimately self-aware slasher camp and--shudder--a sincere relationship thriller, Homecoming hardly seems worth the hour-and-half effort at first.
If nothing else, Homecoming should effectively squelch any movie-star ambition on the part of Mischa Barton, though the camera is more than usually attentive to her cleavage.
Competent but unimaginative.
A bizarre mash-up of Fatal Attraction and Stephen King's Misery, with so many risible premises that it's hard to know where to begin.
Homecoming is Exhibit A in how casting can make--or in this case, break--a genre picture.
Homecoming is coldly efficient for what it is. But what it is is trash.
An unmitigated B-movie that isn't thrilling enough or cheesy enough to make it worth the trip.
Teen thriller/romance is gory but ho-hum. Skip it.

A silly, low-rent mash-up of Misery and Fatal Attraction, featuring neither the clever psychology of the former nor the layers of emasculation and consequence of the latter.
Everything, including the ending, plays out exactly as you'd expect.
As ineffectual police work and broken feet stack up, the silliness gets out of hand.

Rooted by a nice sense of place but, much like its real life namesake, Homecoming isn't age-appropriate for everyone -- maybe just those in high school, or barely removed. Others will likely find the familiarity more humdrum than effectively nostal

When is a movie remake not a movie remake? When the filmmakers involved know what they've made is so wretched they don't dare admit it. The most oblivious MTV viewer won't miss the blatant plagiarism.
